PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr N.A. Brown

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the statement by the Prime Minister in the House last Thursday in which he said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . neither under the law of this country nor under the policy of this Government, is there the practice of compulsory unionism in this country.

In view of that comment, I ask the Minister why, on 8 August, the Government lodged an application with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant employment preference to employees in the Department of Housing and Construction who are members of several specified trade unions as against those who are not union members? Is it not plain that the Government's intention and the only practical effect of preference clauses is to maintain and enforce compulsory unionism in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The incapacity of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to understand basic industrial relations principles never ceases to amaze me. As the Prime Minister said in Question Time last week, we do not have a system of compulsory unionism in this country. There are no awards of the Federal Commission or, to my knowledge, of the State industrial tribunals which provide for compulsory union membership. We do not have a legal system which imposes unionism on unwilling members. In the Conciliation and Arbitration Act we also have, of course, specific provisions for conscientious objection to trade union membership. However, we do have a system in which there are awards which provide for preference to trade unionists. There is a distinct difference between preference to trade unionists and compulsory unionism.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —The horse laughs from honourable members opposite illustrate, as do many other things they do and say, how little they know about industrial relations in this country or, for that matter, in any other country. There is a total difference between being forced to be a member of a trade union and preference being given to union members. A preference system, which is the policy of the Australian Labor Party, encourages people to join trade unions and it gives them some preference in the employment sphere. Indeed, that is appropriate because the whole industrial relations system is based on the fact that trade unions are there to represent employees. Indeed, any industrial relations system must be based on the fact that there are representative bodies for employees. It is also quite common in other countries for preference to apply to trade union members.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no problem and no contradiction with what the Prime Minister said and the actions of the Government in seeking to introduce preference for trade unionists in some areas of government employment. There is no problem with that at all because there is just no contradiction. The fact that the honourable member who asked this question cannot understand the difference between compulsory unionism and preference for trade unionists demonstrates his total incapacity to be the spokesman on industrial relations for the Opposition.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ms Fatin proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Health-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order. The matter is outside the Minister's responsibility.

—I refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to weekend reports that the industrial relations arrangements of Sweden are under study in certain sections of the Australian labour movement. Is it a fact that Sweden has the highest taxes in the Western world and that taxation receipts there are a staggering 51 per cent of gross domestic product? Is it also a fact that Sweden has the biggest spending government in the Western world, with government spending at 64 per cent of gross domestic product? Is it also a fact that the marginal rate of personal tax in Sweden is 75 per cent? Is it also a fact that the latest Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey of the Swedish economy criticised the centralised wage fixation processes of that country for undermining profitability and employment? In those circumstances, can the Minister assure the House that the Government will not seek to emulate Sweden as a model?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see some references in the newspapers to a study of the Swedish economy and industrial relations system. I welcome the fact that that study has been undertaken by the various members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive. I cannot vouch for the alleged facts that have been put forward by the Leader of the Opposition. It is a fact that generally speaking taxes and government expenditure are much higher in Sweden than they are in this country or in many other countries. That has not stopped Sweden from having a very high rate of economic growth, nor has it stopped it from having a standard of living which is well in excess of the standard of living of this country. That does not necessarily mean that that is the approach one should therefore adopt to get a maximum standard of living. I simply note the fact that high levels of taxation and government expenditure do not necessarily-as the Opposition would have us believe-go along with very low levels of economic performance. Indeed, Sweden has been able to keep the unemployment level to around 3 per cent and to maintain a standard of living well in excess of that which prevails in this country. In the post-war period Sweden had much faster rates of economic growth than Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In studying any other country there are lessons to be learnt, but no one can look at another country and transplant what one sees in that country to his or her own country. Nevertheless, we can learn some lessons from it. The Swedish lesson most certainly is that there was a tremendous amount of co-operation between business, trade unions and government during the post-war period to the great benefit of the Swedish people. That co-operative system has prevailed in respect of not only industrial relations but also many other areas of activity and has so marked that country's performance. I believe that it indicates the benefits that can be obtained from a great degree of tripartism.

People who wrote of the Swedish experience in the weekend papers also indicated that they saw the tripartite approach as one which we might follow more fully in this country. This Government has sought very much to develop a tripartite approach, to get away from confrontation and develop a co-operative system. It has established many councils for consultation in various industries and nationally to enable those discussions to take place. We can go much further down that track and we intend to do so. The discussion on Wednesday on work practices will certainly be a further step along that path. We hope that a tripartite approach to discussion on this important area will help to break down some of the unnecessary work practices which have prevailed in this country.

So I have no problems at all with the statements that have been made about Sweden over the weekend. I welcome the fact that trade union members are looking at the experience of other countries and drawing the appropriate lessons. I believe that, in the basic area with which they are concerned, with a co-operative model with a greater emphasis on tripartism we can go further in this country and get the kinds of results which have been obtained in Sweden.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Charles having addressed a question to the Minister for Communications-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's question is out of order. He is once again asking for opinions that are not within the responsibility of the relevant Minister.

—In the absence of Government questions, I direct this question to the Prime Minister: Can the Prime Minister confirm that he has received a letter from the Business Council of Australia expressing concern at the intensification of superannuation claims and also demanding that the Government apply what is referred to as strong and immediate pressure to contain those claims? In view of the latest superannuation push by the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, led by Mr Halfpenny, against Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd, does the Prime Minister now share the Business Council's concern about the increasing cost of pending superannuation claims? I ask the Prime Minister: What, if anything, will his Government do now to contain superannuation claims which show every sign of being reactivated at a time when the Government can least afford it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party for his question. I would say this in response: Yes, I have received a communication from the Business Council of Australia which goes not only to that matter. I take this opportunity of thanking the Business Council for its generally very constructive approach to the whole question of industrial relations. It distinguishes itself from others, including the Opposition and the honourable gentleman who asked the question, in that it sees an enormous amount of merit in the processes of constructive consultation. It repudiates absolutely the processes of confrontation-the attempt to derive some mis- erable advantage from a particular issue that is going at the time. It says to us that, of course, it has concern. I understand its concern about the pressures in the superannuation field. I take this opportunity on that specific issue of saying, quite clearly, not only to the honourable gentleman but also to this House, that we believe that the processes of pressing superannuation claims should be conducted entirely within the framework laid down by the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case which dealt with the issue. This Government gives no aid, comfort or support to any attempt by any union, whatever union it is, to conduct processes outside that framework. One of the reasons why the Business Council of Australia takes such a positive approach in its discussions with this Government, and the reason it will play a constructive part in the meeting to be held the day after tomorrow on work practices, is that it recognises the enormous achievements under this Government's industrial relations policies.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me remind the honourable gentleman opposite, so that perhaps at even this late stage the facts may permeate through his prejudices, that these facts are indisputable: Under the policy of this Government in the industrial relations area, for the first time in the history of this country, in a period of three years of economic growth, there has been an actual reduction in real wages. There has been a reduction of between 4 and 5 per cent in real wages in a period marked by an average of between 4 and 5 per cent growth in non-farm gross domestic product. That has never been done before. That is reflected in the fact that there has been a reduction in real unit labour costs of more than 7 per cent.

That is what has been achieved under this Government. It has been reflected on the other side of the coin by a return to profitability levels of the late 1960s and 1970s against the miserable figure of 12.1 per cent profitability which was the achievement of the Government of which the honourable gentleman was a member in the year 1982-83. That is the achievement which at the same time has been marked by a lowering in the level of industrial disputation of about 53 per cent. Those are the facts. There has been a lower level of industrial disputation, a return to high levels of profitability, a reduction in real wages, and a reduction of over 7 per cent in real unit labour costs. Is it any wonder, in those circumstances, that not only the Business Council of Australia but most other relevant employer organisations say, `Congratulations to this Government for producing those results and a plague upon you who would seek to reintroduce the processes of confrontation in this country'?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is for the Minister for Communications. The Opposition spokesman on communications, the honourable member for Goldstein, said in this House last Thursday night:

QUESTION.PARA: The next step for us is to take the Government head on in any legislation which it now proposes.
He was referring to aggregation and multi-channel services. Does the Government propose any such legislation, and what would be the effect if any such legislation were not passed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I listened with great interest to the honourable member for Goldstein when he stated that the Opposition would oppose any legislation that would attempt to pave the way for the aggregation of regional television markets.
—Hear, hear!

—It is all very well for the honourable member to say `Hear, hear', but it may come as a shock to all Opposition members to know that we do not necessarily require legislation to implement the Government's policy of aggregation. The honourable member for Goldstein appears not to understand-on the basis of the interjection, I suppose that the vast majority of Opposition members do not understand-that under the service based provisions of the Broadcasting Act the Minister for Communications has the power to determine and vary service areas. Anyone who has followed this matter will know that the redrawing of service areas is the most likely route to achieve aggregation.

ANSWER.PARA: That brings me to the other point of the honourable member's question. The Government's policy of equalisation allows the introduction of new services by aggregation, or multi-channel services in approved markets. But in some areas of Australia, such as South Australia, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and some isolated markets within the eastern States, the Government will encourage a second commercial service via multi-channel services only, because clearly, throughout this whole matter, the Government has recognised that not all areas will be able to go to equalisation. The purpose of the proposed legislation to which the honourable member for Goldstein referred is to bring about those multi-channel services. Blocking that legislation would mean that multi-channel services will not be introduced.

It is worth those opposite thinking for a little while about what the effect of their actions will be. Let me explain that to them. People living, for example, in Mount Isa, Broken Hill, Berri, Mount Gambier, Port Pirie, Albany, Bunbury, Kalgoorlie, Geraldton and Darwin will have no opportunity to receive new commercial services if the Opposition persists with the course mentioned in this House last Thursday night. It should be clearly understood by all the people living in the areas mentioned that if they do not get new commercial television services, it will be the fault of the Opposition parties in this House, with the help of the Australian Democrats in the Senate. It will not be the fault of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware that a women's health care pamphlet prepared by the Leichhardt Women's Community Health Centre and distributed through some schools to year 10 girls at compulsory health and welfare days recommends, among other things, the use of marihuana as a muscle relaxant, and the use of alcohol, straight or mixed, to enlarge the blood vessels in the pelvic area and give increased pain tolerance, and orgasm, by masturbation, intercourse or any other way that takes one's fancy, to reduce period pain? Is this appropriate advice to be given to young schoolgirls as part of a personal development course? Is this advice on alcohol and marihuana from a centre funded by the Minister's department consistent with the Government's $100m drug offensive? Will the Minister investigate this matter and stop funding attempts to push marihuana and alcohol to schoolgirls?

—I am not aware of the pamphlet referred to by the honourable member; nor, of course, am I responsible for the operation of community health centres. They are the responsibility of State government. But I will take up the issue with the State Government concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In view of the good case South Australia has made for the contract for the new fleet of submarines-specifically its proposed `Green Fields' site on the Port River at Osborne-has the Government decided on the site where the new fleet for the Royal Australian Navy will be built? Can the Minister assure the House that the eventual site selection will be based on merit and will not be a political decision? Finally, if the decision has not yet been made, can the Minister tell the House when it will be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can absolutely guarantee to the honourable gentleman that the decision on the site will be made on the basis of merit and not politics. We are very good at making decisions based on merit as opposed to concern about this or that political interest. I have noticed a great deal of reporting of the comments of a variety of State task forces on the subject of the submarine project. We very much welcome their attention to the project. As a result of their attention, an excellent relationship has been established between the companies which are doing the project definition studies and Australian industry. A real appreciation has developed between the companies and Australian companies which may find themselves involved in the submarine project. As a result, the designs of the various submarines are being modified to suit Australian industrial capabilities. The close integration which has occurred throughout the project definition phase will be a very substantial advantage when one of the tenderers is selected and we proceed to construct the submarines.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision on the location of the site for the assembly of the submarines will be made early in the new year, when the overall designs are considered and when the two propositions that will be put forward to the Government later this year are considered. The types of considerations which will come into play in determining merit will be, of course, very substantially commercial and, to a degree, strategic. The commercial consideration, of course, will include a plethora of matters and will not necessarily relate only to the immediate costs of the site, but to the sorts of industries that would support it. It will relate, too, to questions of the industrial relations regime that will operate at the yard. A whole variety of factors will come into play. South Australia has put forward a very good bid in that regard. As I expressed in this place some time ago in the course of the South Australian elections, it will take a lot of catching. I still stand by that proposition.

In conclusion, we have welcomed the considerable attention that this issue has received from the State governments of New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia. Indeed, the Tasmanians and Queenslanders have also been involved. It has all been to the good of the project. It has been very effective in demonstrating the capabilities of Australian industry to the two project definition study people. It amplifies the effectiveness of that type of selection process. As a result of that, we will arrive at both the right location for assembly and the right submarine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport to his letter to me of 7 July 1986 in which he said that it would not be appropriate for him `to intervene on the question of Qantas providing travel assistance' and that `requests for special fares or travel assistance are matters for the airlines to assess on the basis of their commercial judgment'. Why did the Government apply this standard to a teacher wishing to attend a deaf children's conference in Chicago and yet allow public servants, including the Executive Director of the Trade Development Council, successfully to demand four free seats for the Australian Council of Trade Unions on a taxpayer-funded `study tour'?

—The reply that I gave to the honourable member was based upon the information that he provided at the time. I repeat for his benefit, and for the information of the House, that decisions of that nature are made by the airline exercising its commercial judgment. In respect of the other matter, I am not aware of the details. I shall be happy to make inquiries and provide the honourable member with the details in a proper form at a later date.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and concerns the Australian film and television industry, which has attracted such favourable comment recently. I refer specifically to successes at the Cannes Film Festival and other recent successes in the industry including Crocodile Dundee which has enjoyed remarkable popularity and which was filmed in beautiful Kakadu National Park. Can the Minister explain why this success is occurring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our success at Cannes has recently been repeated at the Montreal Film Festival, where 11 of our films were invited to participate. Crocodile Dundee was selected for the gala screening and received a tremendous response. On Wednesday night, I shall be showing, as previewing here, one of the films selected for the Cannes festival, entitled The Fringe Dwellers, and also Peel, the winner of the best short-film award at Cannes.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that honourable members will be interested to know the details of the success of Crocodile Dundee. The gross box office earnings in Australia have already exceeded $27m, and that has broken every record in Australian cinema history. It has broken the record for all films and not just for a locally made product. Approximately six million Australians have seen the film. At Mount Isa, some 32,500 people have seen the film, and the population of Mount Isa is only 17,500. In a few days time-on 26 September-the movie will open in America, and I would not be surprised if its box office receipts there exceed $100m. It will add enormously to Australia's export earnings. One of the benefits that have already accrued is that for Australian release a record number of 93 colour prints were produced at Colourfilm at Sydney, and a further 500 prints have been produced for American release. An order for an additional 200 is expected for other international release. I think that this is an outstanding order as normally 60 is considered a good order.

This is an opportunity to congratulate the producers of the film, Paul Hogan, John Cornell and Terry Jackman, on the job that they have done for Australia. I know that my colleague, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, says that his tourism budget has been cut back slightly. At least he has Crocodile Dundee showing for the next three months in the United States, which means that he will not need any money. Well, he will not need as much as he would have done otherwise.

The production of these films has been helped greatly by Division 10ba tax incentives, which have been maintained and strengthened. It is appropriate that the Opposition, which introduced these tax incentives, should state clearly what it proposes to do in future. Rumours are rife in the industry of the incentives being stopped if the Opposition gets into power. In the whole area of the arts the Opposition needs to put its position. It is allowing those in the arts commun- ity and the film industry to believe that under its new regime, if it ever came into power-God forbid-the benefits would be ended.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Will he either confirm or deny that taxpayers wishing to challenge decisions of the Australian Taxation Office will be required to lodge a $200 deposit as a filing fee to have the tax dispute considered formally? If confirmed, will the Treasurer tell us whether the fee will be refundable under any circumstances and whether interest is to be paid thereon when there is a lengthy dispute? Does the Treasurer agree that such a fee will be a barrier to many taxpayers who consider they have a legitimate basis on which to challenge a decision of the Australian Taxation Office?

—The taxpayer can still challenge an assessment of the Taxation Office but if he wishes to take the matter to appeal the $200 fee is payable. I would need to refresh my memory about the conditions of any repayment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. What would be the effect on Medicare if the abolition of fringe benefits, capital gains and lump sum superannuation taxes were funded from it, as suggested by the Leader of the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of statements made over the weekend on this matter by the Leader of the Opposition. They can reveal only either an abysmal ignorance of health economics or a rather callous regard for the less well off in this society. Let me deal first of all with the rather shoddy economics. If these taxes he has suggested were abolished the cost to revenue would be $660m. If his proposal went through people could opt out of the levy, but if the same happened as in 1976, that is the upper segment of the population opted out, lost revenue would be $950m. Therefore the cost to revenue of the proposals put forward would be some $1,600m.
—What do they take out in costs?

—Of course, as the interrupter points out, some of that money, approximately $1 billion, would be saved in medical benefit payments. The actual costs of the proposal are $600m, and they include nothing such as the tax rebate losses which have been talked about or the renewed subsidies to private hospitals. I repeat, the cost would be $600m.

ANSWER.PARA: It is about time the Leader of the Opposition recognised that there are only two ways in the health Budget in which the sort of moneys he talks about can be saved: One is by doubling the levy to 2.5 per cent, as his Government did in 1976 when it introduced exactly the same scheme; and the second is by saving the money by removing the free medical provisions for pensioners and the disadvantaged. They are the only two ways in which those changes can be made. These people opposite are suggesting that the Government simply shift the balance of payment from the well off to those less well off in the community. As the absurdities of those proposals are revealed we would have exactly the same situation as we had under Fraser-a new health scheme every 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the officer shortage in the Royal Australian Navy is now so grave that the Department of Defence has been forced to offer special and unusual re-employment packages to retired Navy officers in order to fill senior and presently unoccupied positions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation with regard to officers in all the Services is not as has been portrayed by the Opposition spokesman on defence or in a number of complaints that have been made in the Press over the last week or two. There are many factors in the officer shortage related both to the Navy and to the other Services, some of which I do believe relate to conditions. Since we have been in office we have gone through a process of substantially upgrading the access of the Services to community type arbitral processes, which they very much wanted and which they are taking advantage of. Through those processes we have substantially addressed some of the problems associated with the officers' level of income. We have also gone through the process, and are still going through the pro- cess, of improving service housing conditions. Despite the fact that this was a tough Budget for us, we were able to maintain expenditure on housing, for example, which is a problematic area, to the tune of some $66m. We are devising various ways, via remuneration packages, of approaching the problem. As far as I am aware, the particular process which the honourable member suggested has not been proceeded with. However, a variety of matters are being considered in regard to remuneration packages which may from time to time come across my desk and go to the remuneration Tribunal.

ANSWER.PARA: Unlike the Opposition, in addressing this pro- cess systematically we are not simply regarding this problem as one associated only with remun- eration, although it has its remuneration component. There are many factors to be considered in the current rate of officer loss, not the least of which could reasonably be described as a Vietnam bulge proceeding through. In the 1960s there was heavy recruitment. Those officers recruited and maintained within the Services in the 1960s are now leaving them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the reason.

—It is correct. That assessment is not just my assessment; that is the advice that came to me from the three Service chiefs, who are addressing that problem. There is also the factor of lifestyle. There is no doubt that the type of lifestyle which members of the Services have lived, with constant shifts and changes, is becoming problematic to a large number of people in the Services, particularly those who see the Services as a long term career, such as naval officers and the officers in the other two Services. That is a very difficult problem to address; it is a problem that will be with us for some time. It relates to the number of times people shift, the employment opportunities for families and the types of housing opportunities they would like as opposed to those that are readily provided. Over the next few years I think it will be very difficult to arrive at conclusions that are satisfactory to them.

ANSWER.PARA: The possibilities of encouraging re-enlistment via processes of bonuses and the like are not decisions we have taken at this point. Those sorts of suggestions have been circulated, but I do not tend to favour them as the means of addressing the problem. I think it has to be addressed in a much more complex fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to a report in the Sunday Telegraph of yesterday that the Government has not taken up a personal offer from President Reagan to station two members of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency in Australia? Will he inform the House of the Government's position about that issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fraser for his question. I have seen the report. It comes on top of a question asked of me after Question Time last week by the honourable member for Gilmore regarding something he had heard or discussed with a member of the United States Embassy about an offer made by the United States President to send two members of the Drug Enforcement Agency to Australia. I was not aware of the offer. Normally the President would write not to my office but to someone else, but I would normally hear of it from the law enforcement area. I had not heard of the offer, and I said that I would get back to the honourable member, but before I could do that he took up the political option and put an article in the Sunday Press-that there had been an offer by President Reagan to Australia to supply us with two senior members of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency; they would help us overcome the drug war which we are losing in Australia; and that the honourable member was astounded that not a single move had been made by me to investigate the offer. I have investigated the offer, and I am advised that a lot of other people are astounded-because no one has heard of the offer. To date, there have been discussions in Washington between me and both Judge Webster of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Director of the Drug Enforcement Agency, between Judge Stewart and both agencies and between the Police Commissioner and both agencies. In 1985 there were discussions in Australia as to whether a United States drug enforcement agent should be in Australia. As I pointed out to the honourable member, the United States Embassy has a person designated to handle these matters at the Embassy in Canberra.

ANSWER.PARA: We made it perfectly clear to the United States authorities some time ago that we would have no objection to a person being placed in Australia in the same way and in exactly the same capacity as our Australian Federal Police people are placed in Washington and Los Angeles. We would have to decide on where they were based, and whether it ought to be Sydney or Canberra is the subject of some debate. Of course the United States people in Australia would be in the same position as our people in Washington. They would not be operatives as they are in some other parts of the world. To all intents and purposes no one can pinpoint any offer made by President Reagan. I felt that it may have come in a major statement which the President was to make last week. As the House knows, the United States is again placing great emphasis on this massive problem with which it is confronted. Although some people are becoming a little cynical about the way it is doing it, I notice in the latest Time magazine the following passage:

The rush by lawmakers and Government officials to pass antidrug legislation and prove their own purity by submitting to urinalysis has provoked the mirth of columnists and the sighs of weary legislators who have lived through earlier drug crises. New York Times Columnist William Safire writes mockingly of `drugocrats' waging `jar wars'. Shrugs Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan: `we're all going to drug conferences and making the Secretary of State pee into a paper cup.'

So not everybody adopts the same attitude about the way the United States is going about these things. I notice that even the President himself had his urine tested in August for evidence of drug abuse in order to prove how far the United States is prepared to go. We have not heard from the President about this offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to give us a specimen?
—I was going to suggest, since those opposite are all running dead at Question Time, that we get Madam Speaker to arrange it for them. They must be on a go slow drug.
—Sit down and we will get the call.

—The honourable member is not using Question Time so why does he not wait for a bit of information? The honourable member asked a question last week; he will not get the call for two years. Unless he can ask a question better than the one he asked last week, he should not get the call for two years. We thought the honourable member was here to get information. I do not know whether Bill Payne is in the Press gallery, but he writes articles for the Sunday Telegraph. He said that I admitted, in answer to a question the honourable member for Gilmore asked me last week, that the Federal Police are now operating a nine-to-five operation. That is not what I said. I said that the police determine themselves the resources they have-and they have been greatly enlarged by this Government; how they will use those resources; and what their priorities are. No major crime has not been investigated in the way the Australian Federal Police wanted to investigate it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his admission last week that the authorities are now intervening to support the Australian dollar at a level of round 60c, which appears to countermand the following statement contained in the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia:

QUESTION.PARA: The Bank has not sought to establish any particular exchange rate.

Given the 17 per cent decline in Australia's reserves during the last four months, how long does the Government believe this direct intervention by the Reserve Bank can go on, or will the Government rely on higher interest rates to support the Australian dollar? Given the prospect of continued high interest rates, can the Treasurer confirm that the Government still expects 135,000 new dwelling commencements in the current financial year as foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his 2 April housing statement, or will the level of commencements fall below the 135,000 he guaranteed, placing extra pressure on home owners and unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition seeks to misrepresent what I said last week. What I did last week was comment on market judgments. I was neither confirming nor denying those judgments. The House might find it useful for me to read the quote. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: I think the market will probably assume therefore that there is probably a floor on the Australian dollar and . . . it is not an assumption I would disabuse them of. This of course reflects judgments about monetary policy, the attendant interest rates and the history of the bank's own market interventions . . .

They are judgments that the market may well choose to make. I was commenting on what I believed to be the current judgment of the market; nothing more and nothing less. In relation to housing lending, deposit growth has still been running strongly in the three months to July. Lending from savings banks has been running at around $7.5 billion a year whereas the Government, on the basis of its arrangements with the banks, has talked in terms of a figure of $6 billion. I have no indications to date that the deposit growth, which was running very strongly up until July, has tapered off since July; so I have no basis for altering the assumption of 135,000 starts across the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism advise the House of the results that Australia achieved at the International Disabled Games, the short name of which is FESPIC, which were recently held in Java?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Greenway, in very similar terms to the honourable member for Wide Bay, has always exhibited a very deep interest in the participation of the disabled in sport in Australia. At the recent FESPIC Games, where Australia was represented by amputee, wheelchair and blind athletes, I am happy to tell the House that Australia won 104 gold medals, 44 silver medals and 28 bronze medals, which made us the top nation in the world in disabled sport, as we have been at every recent disabled games from the Disabled Olympics down. I think every member of the House, including the Leader of the Opposition, should be very proud of the achievements of Australia's disabled athletes. But strangely enough, I came back on the early plane from Adelaide to farewell our athletes to this FESPIC Games on behalf of the Government, and thereby on behalf of the Australian public, and while sitting in the airport waiting to meet the athletes I noticed a little quote in the Sydney Morning Herald, which said: `Howard questions need for sports funding'. The article went on to say that others might see this as a heresy but that he did not.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, I presume that we are entitled to look back at the record of this particular group of people who were in government for 30-odd of the last 37 years. If we do that, we realise how little they did for sport. I inform the House that this Government will contribute $1m to disabled sport this year-to the elite disabled athletes right down to those people who have been stuck away on verandahs for years and who have had no place in sport in Australia. The record of honourable members opposite for funding disabled sport was just nothing, nil. When they talk about reducing funds for sport they might note that funds for sport contributed by this Government are 0.006 per cent of Budget outlays, which is just 600 per cent more than they ever gave for sport. I presume that we can look at their record and think that that is what we will go back to. Therefore, I wonder whether we should believe that the Surf Life Saving Association, which this year is to get $1m from this Government to continue its work, should go back to the $100,000 they used to give it, or that the Royal Life Saving Society, which is charged with teaching Australian kids how to swim, can look forward to going back to $100,000 instead of the $350,000 it will get this year. The same thing can be repeated in respect of a dozen other organisations. I suppose our Olympic athletes will go back to running chook raffles, like they used to do during the term of office of the previous Government, so that they can attend Olympic games, whereas under this Government they received $1.4m. I know that honourable members opposite believe that is too much. It happens to be 10c per head of population every four years-2 1/2c a year-but honourable members opposite think it is too much.

If honourable members opposite want to start winding the clock back on sports funding, they should do so at their own peril because in the next 18 months I will be out telling all of those sporting organisations that we fund-100 organisations representing six million Australians-that, if by some unfortunate set of events those opposite happen to be in government again, they can look forward to what they got previously, which was nothing, and that they can look forward to the funding that existed before Mr Hawke became the Prime Minister. The previous Government did not support sport and Australia then had the highest level of heart disease in the world because Australians were not participating in sport. Australians are now participating. I am very happy to tell the House that participation in sport in the last three years has been 200 per cent higher at the grass roots level than it ever was under the previous Government. If honourable members opposite want to carry on with some proposition such as `Howard questions need for sport funding', they can carry on. There is enormous support for us in the sporting community of Australia, and I will spend the next 18 months telling it that poor old Rambo over there, who purports to be the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism-if we can believe the ramblings of John Stone, the alter ego of the Leader of the Opposition, that my Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism is laughable-will not have a department at all if he ever gets into government. Under this Government, funding for sport will continue at its current high level, particularly for the disabled athletes who performed so brilliantly in Java.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY BUSH FIRE COUNCIL

—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Blunt,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Robert Brown,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Chynoweth,Mr Cowan,Mr Drummond,Mr Hand,Mr Hollis,Mr Hurford,Mr Kent,Mr Keogh,Mr Lee,Mr Miles,Mr Porter,Mr Rocher,Mr Snow,Mr Tickner,Mr Tuckey and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chynoweth,Mr Hawker,Mr Hurford and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependents who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.

Your petitioners humbly pray that: family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI; the dependent spouse rebate be retained; the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Miles.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That families have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of their net disposable income through:
failure to index family allowances-resulting in a 50% loss in their real value since 1976
abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18-even those still at school
failure to increase the spouse rebate since 1982
discriminatory taxation system-which penalises single income families.
Recognising the cost benefit to taxpayers when the intact family unit itself delivers essential care to the extended family.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take immediate action to:
Restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them to cover future price rises
Introduce optional income-splitting for taxation purposes
Retain the spouse rebate.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Saunderson and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Mssrs. Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act, refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amended in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell and Mr Drummond.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian Government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 Budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ruddock and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you do not proceed with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Purchase of 196 Lutwyche Road, Windsor, by Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The undersigned citizens of Australia do humbly petition:
That the proposed sale by the Brisbane City Council of property at 196 Lutwyche Road, Windsor, Brisbane, to Australia Post for use as a transport depot would:
(a) increase industrial traffic congestion in the general area
(b) occupy existing scarce open space area in a relatively high density residential area
(c) increase noise for residents adjacent to the site
(d) increase traffic congestion and noise for residents in streets used by vehicles from the proposed transport depot
(e) increase traffic flow along Rosemount Terrace which is a relatively narrow street and currently ill-equipped to cope with increased traffic
(f) increase the traffic hazards at either end of Rosemount Terrace as both ends already constitute potential traffic dangers, particularly the corner of Newmarket Road and Rosemount Terrace
(g) increase traffic congestion at the Newmarket Road/Lutwyche Road `T' junction
(h) lead to development of the site which could obstruct the easterly view of residents in Rosemount Terrace
(i) worsen the visual pollution of the Lutwyche Road corridor, the main arterial route from the northern suburbs of Brisbane to the city centre.
Your petitioners do therefore humbly pray that the Parliament use its powers to prevent Australia Post from proceeding with negotiations to acquire property at 196 Lutwyche Road, Windsor, Brisbane.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefit tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Standards and Screening Hours
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives, of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
Because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
Because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
Because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
Because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
Because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
Because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
Because we believe that the standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to ``the story line'' of a film screened,

Because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
Because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
And because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations:
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages:
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business:
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representative in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Wollongong Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the closure of the Wollongong area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethic Affairs.

2. That the impact of the closure of the office in Wollongong will be particularly felt by the non-English speaking migrants and community at large from Shoalhaven to Helensburgh and as far as Wingecarribee and Wollondilly.

Your petitions therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that the area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Wollongong is kept operational and fully staffed.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Lalor/Thomastown
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully show that the lack of a Medicare office in Lalor/Thomastown is seriously inconveniencing the residents of the Shire of Whittlesea.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare office be established in Lalor/Thomastown as soon as possible.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
In this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
That such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiations of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
That such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would
Be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to:
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

And, to the Australian Government. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
Inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilizing nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
Arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
Upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time; (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All federal members of Parliament and senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners wish that all medicines prescribed by a registered Medical Practitioner be made available free of charge by the Government to all pensioners for the following reasons:
1. The enormous cost of some drugs, including pain relieving ones, not at present on the ``free list''.
2. That certain drugs essential for permanently disabled, such as epileptics are at present being charged for and therefore present a great financial burden to the pensioner.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will consider our wishes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian background respectfully showeth:
we most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

we are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its' interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
we respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australian Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's action on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: `Fair Go for Women' Survey
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that the 1986 Census deprived housewives of the right to record their occupation and instead forced them to give the negative response: `No, did not have a job'.
That the 1986 Census could have been used, at no extra cost to taxpayers, to give a genuine `Fair Go' to all women to record their views on the government's National Agenda for Women.

That coinciding with the 1986 Census, the Office of the Status of Women is conducting a costly, selective survey titled: `A Fair Go For Women'. This survey requires no identification of respondents, making the results of the survey highly suspect since it is known that various groups and individuals have obtained bulk supplies of the brochure, while the majority of women are not aware that their views are being sought by the Government.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will restore to the Census a category for Housewives, and that the `Fair Go For Women' survey will be recognised as a costly exercise of dubious value in determining the real views of Australian women, as this should be done through the Census, or a Referendum held in conjunction with the next Federal Election to minimise costs, and to give all women a genuine `Fair Go'.
