DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's belated and inadequate response to the need to remove restrictive work practices.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week's death-bed conversion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the cause of removing restrictive work practices must be viewed with an enormous amount of cynicism. We say that because we now have a Prime Minister who is trying to present himself as some form of born-again reformer on the issue of removing work practices which are restrictive. How uncomfortably, we must say at the outset, that must lie in the mouth of a Prime Minister who has probably spent the past 25 years of this life embarked upon a course of expanding trade union power that has enabled restrictive work practices to be imposed on our economy. But, like most of his attempts at reform, we are seeing from this Prime Minister a response that is completely inadequate; it is too little and it comes to late. The Prime Minister is prepared to fiddle around at the edges of work practices and call yet another conference to talk about them, but he is not prepared to tackle the root cause of the whole scandal, and that is the rigidity and the inflexibility of our industrial relations system. Against the reform of that antiquated structure, the Prime Minister and his Government have firmly set their faces.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me start by looking not at what the Opposition says about our present industrial relations system but at what is said about it by one of the many international observers that have recently come to judge it. It is important that we remember that the following comment was made by an independent observer. On Australia's day of shame-that is what 10 September was-Moody's Investor Services Inc. took away our AAA rating. One of the reasons it gave for reaching the conclusion that it should reduce us from our AAA rating was put by Moody's in the following words:
Industrial and labor market rigidities are further expected to hamper the country's ongoing efforts to shift economic resources into areas with high foreign exchange earning capacity.

That is what Moody's has said, and amongst all the welter of comment that has been made arising out of that matter, it is well to remember that Moody's emphasised the rigidities and inflexibility in our present industrial relations system.

So there it is, as plain as anyone could wish. Australia's economic success and the way the world is judging Australia are now both being held back by our rigid industrial relations system-a system that is one reason, although of course not the only reason, for our worsening economic performance, our flagging trade, our high interest rates, our rising inflation, our falling dollar and our mounting debt. One result of this rigid system, which has now been condemned by so many international observers and which the Australian community is coming to realise is one of the features of our country which is holding back our development, is the creeping paralysis of restrictive work practices-practices that add so much to our costs and practices that hold back so much of our potential productivity growth.

If anyone has any doubt about this problem, let me rely not upon what we in the Opposition say but upon the comments of one who has had a second look and has thought again about the way in which this country is going. I refer to Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon-a man with a history of involvement in the trade union and labour movement going back over many years. He said:

. . . improving the ability of our industries to compete against intensifying competition both at home and abroad requires reform in the area of restrictive work practices . . . It is more than possible that I have contributed on a number of occasions to either their introduction or at least their continuance.
At least he has more honesty about him than the present Prime Minister. He went on to say:
However much I may have erred in past years, I long ago recognised that most of such practices do not assist industry to provide optimum results for its workforce and therefore they are useless-
I repeat the word `useless'-
impediments to progress.

That is what Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon has said. Let there be no doubt that this is a major problem facing this country. Restrictive work practices are widespread throughout our industries. For example, the Metal Trades Industry Association has conducted a survey and has found that, believe it or not, 80 per cent of employees have been and are engaged in a wide number of restrictive work practices that add so much to costs and keep our productivity down. Examples of them are legion. There is gross overmanning, especially in sea-going and transport industries, in stevedoring and on the waterfront. Some unions insist that work not be done during normal hours so that overtime must be paid for. Demarcation disputes have been made an art form, with unions using their muscle to force employers to engage several people to do one job.

The list goes on. Companies are bludgeoned into employing shop stewards on a full time basis under threat of strikes. In one case that came to my notice, a separate shop steward had to be employed to supervise only four employees in his trade. Extravagant allowances have been forced through our centralised system for almost any spurious reason that seems to fit the mood. To take an extreme example, but one from the real world, on one building site in Sydney the workers apparently were distracted by the smell of Chinese cooking and they applied for and successfully got a dim sim allowance. Those are the absurd lengths to which this work practices scandal has gone.

Absenteeism is a national disgrace. The unions impose bans on outside contractors to force employers to keep larger work forces than they need. Operators and process workers are prevented from making even the simplest repairs to the machinery on which they themselves work. Stop work meetings are held for spurious reasons. New technology is frequently banned with all the zeal of the Luddites. Awards are riddled with clauses on non-productive time-time that is not worked but is, of course, paid for. Penalty rates and loadings are an international joke. If on occasion a supervisor in an industry uses a simple tool to perform a simple task, there can be a mass walk-out.

In addition to all of that, we have the most restrictive and pernicious work practice of all-compulsory unionism, which this Government supports. While I am at it, may I say what an absurd explanation we had today of the very point that the Opposition is making. Here is the Government applying for preference clauses, enforcing preference clauses, using preference clauses to ensure that people who are members of a certain union get a job over, above and against those who are not members of that union and who do not get a job. It is the utmost hypocrisy for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister to say: `Of course, there are preference clauses in this country, but there is no closed shop and no compulsory unionism'. It is absolutely absurd, for the simple reason that if one is a member of the union one gets the job and if one is not a member of the union one does not get the job. If that is not compulsory unionism, I do not know what is. What the Opposition says about that most pernicious work practice is that we will repeal the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant preference clauses in awards.

The problem, then, is extensive. But what a contrast there has been between the Government's response and the Opposition's response. What has the Government done? It has made three equally absurd and equally inadequate responses. The first response was the most hysterical outburst by the Prime Minister against the good faith of those who wanted nothing more than to reform our industrial relations system. They have been abused as being lunatics and troglodytes. The Prime Minister stood by and allowed one of his Ministers, without any reprimand, to describe them as traitors. Let me make it clear that we do not need any lectures about extremism from members of the Labor Party. If they want to root out extremism, they should start by looking at their own Party and do something about one of their Senate candidates who was, until a couple of years ago, a member of the most extreme movement in Australia, namely, the Communist Party of Australia. If they want to start criticising people for extremism, they should, as with charity, begin at home and dump Mr Halfpenny completely from their Senate ticket.

The second response that the Government adopted, of course, was the time honoured Hawke method of calling a mini-summit. We say that it is all very well to talk about these issues. Of course, it is good to talk about them. But our criticism of the Government is related to the fact that it has open to it avenues to bring about reform of restrictive trade practices and work practices. Of course, it can do something about management practices as well. But if there is a problem about restrictive work practices, as there clearly is, it is in the hands of the Government to do something positive about it. It is not enough for it to say: `We will have a summit and then we will withdraw', to use its words. `We will walk away from it and leave the unions and the peak employer councils to solve the problem themselves'. That is an abrogation of government responsibility.

It is within the power of the Government to change our industrial relations laws, to enable employers and employees to get together to work out their own incentive based arrangements, to work out conditions of employment for themselves and, for the first time, to have a say about what their work is worth, what they should be paid and what work conditions should exist in their place of employment. It is the responsibility of the Government to do something positive to bring about a more flexible wage fixing system in this country. That was its second response-to have a mini-summit and then walk away from it, instead of changing the industrial relations law, as it should, to allow more flexibility and more work based incentive arrangements between employers and employees. If the Government did that, it would get rid of restrictive work practices.

The Government's third response, of course, is the most absurd and ludicrous of all. Apparently we are now to look towards the Swedish corporate state for our inspiration. It should come as no surprise, I suppose, to anyone that the Labor Party and its hand maidens in the trade union movement now see the light on the hill as coming from Sweden. After all, is not that the country which has all of the things which the Labor Party is trying to force on Australia? It has the highest taxes in the industrialised world. Taxation in that country represents more than 50 per cent of gross domestic product. It has the highest corporate taxes, which have destroyed individual initiative in that country. It is a country which has extraordinary controls and regulations. Above all, just to show how ignorant one of the economic Ministers of this Government is, I point out that it is not a country which has a long record of substantial economic growth. If the Minister is going to make these wild assertions he should back them up.

We do not need Sweden as a model. We need our own model of less taxation and less government spending. We want our own model of less intervention, less regulation and far more incentive. Above all, in this country we need an industrial relations model with less regulation and less trade union power, which the Labor Party can never bring about because it is wedded to the trade union movement and paid by it. We need more incentives for individual employers and their employees to make their own bargains, which will bring about increased productivity at the work place at the enterprise level.

We do not need any foreign flirting with the Swedish experiment. As I have said, we need our own model. We know what the country needs and it is up to the Government to provide it if it can, but we say that the Australian people will recognise sooner or later that this Government cannot provide it and will turn to the Opposition. The worst feature of all is that the Government has within its own hands the power to change our system to get more productivity from our industry. However, against that reform, which is so needed, the Government has set its face. It should be condemned for its lack of activity and its half-hearted response to the need to reform work practices. Like so many other things in this country, we need a new industrial relations system that will restore incentive once again, and above all we need a new government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone listening to the debate would assume from the speech of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) that restrictive work practices came into being only when the Government came to office. That is an absolute nonsense. As every Opposition member knows and as everybody outside the House knows, restrictive work practices have been built up within the system over many years. When we came into office in March 1983, this country was in very bad economic shape. Some of the reasons for that were fairly recent events but some of them went back decades. They went back to the policies that had been pursued by government in the post-war period.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983, Australia was basically what Liberal-National Party coalition governments had made it. Australia had been governed for 30 of the 33 years since the end of the 1940s by Liberal-National/Country Party governments. They had built up an economy which was grossly inefficient by world standards and which gave us low levels of productivity. It was an economy which was falling far below its potential and it relied on the lucky country syndrome-the fact that we were able to find minerals and that we had a very efficient rural industry. Previous governments had given us a manufacturing industry base which was grossly inefficient, highly protected and unable to be internationally competitive. That was our legacy when we came into office in March 1983.

We have set about redressing the Australian economy on many fronts, and that has meant meeting the need to produce a rapid growth in employment, which we were certainly able to do in our first three years in government. That has not been merely a short term focus. We have been emphasising from the outset the need to make all the productive forces of our nation more productive than they have been in the past, and we have tackled the issue on various fronts. It is grossly untrue to say, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said many times during his speech, that this Government has responded only latterly and inadequately. Since we came into office, we have been on various fronts attacking the need to achieve greater productivity so that we can realise something like our real potential. In the process of doing that we have in various areas addressed the issue of restrictive work practices.

I guess that the first such area was in relation to the steel plan. In our very early days we established a plan for the steel industry, an industry which was in dire difficulties when we came into office. Indeed its very future was being questioned. We set about establishing a plan for that industry which would ensure its future viability and make it much more productive and efficient, and we were able to do that. The target which was set to be achieved over a number of years in respect of output per man was achieved in about a year and a half; that is, we achieved an output of about 250 tonnes per man year. That target was set in the very early stages to be achieved over several years, and it was a very gratifying result. It was accompanied by a very substantial reduction in industrial disputation and has meant that that industry has become far more efficient than it was under the previous Government. That was just the first of a number of such plans which have been adopted. Latterly we have adopted the heavy engineering industry plan which again specifically went to the question of the need to improve work practices. Part of the agreed plan is that the parties will discuss and eliminate unnecessary work practices. The unions were very co-operative in relation to that clause in the agreement.

Let me now refer to the car industry which, under the previous Government, was allowed to become grossly inefficient, massively protected and hopelessly organised. We have set about establishing a plan for that industry to make it much more competitive and productive. We established the Automotive Industry Consultative Council-a tripartite body-which has discussed various ways of making the industry more efficient. Various steps have been taken to achieve that, including the introduction of the `just in time' principle, which eliminates the costly need for substantial warehousing and enables industry to get by with products being delivered just as they are needed for production purposes. That has been a great saver to the industry and it has also required various changes in work practices to enable that system to be introduced. The unions went along with that as a perceived part of the need to make the industry more efficient and to ensure that there were jobs for their members.

In those various industry plans specific attention has been given to the need to increase productivity and to eliminate restrictive work practices. In none of those industries was any of this kind of activity undertaken by the previous Government, nor can I think of any other industry in which it was undertaken. That Government sat there decade after decade, allowing all these things to occur and allowing Australians to be massively inefficient, allowing industry to be built up under massive protection which encouraged all those inefficient practices, and it did nothing about it. Then, when it got into opposition, it tried to prove how righteous it was by saying that this Government ought to be doing more about restrictive work practices when we have done infinitely more in our three years in government than it did in 30 years in government.

In respect of our own area of employment, where we have a particular obligation to set an example, we have undertaken a very substantial examination of various work practices in the Public Service and in other areas of government employment. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will make a speech in this House later this week which will give the details of that examination. He will demonstrate that we are very concerned to ensure that we have a much more efficient Public Service in this country and that we eliminate the various inefficiencies which were allowed to foster under the previous Government. We are, right in our own area of employment, making a very profound effort to improve the efficiency of the Public Service as well as various other areas of government employment such as factories and so on. I believe the Opposition is utterly hypocritical in saying that the Government should be doing more to eliminate restrictive work practices when it sat there for decades when in government doing nothing and allowed it all to happen. Now when it is in opposition it complains about the Government, which is doing far more than it did and which is taking substantial steps, and says we are doing nothing. The reference by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to Moody's Investor Services Inc. was indeed interesting. He indicated that Moody's had said that one of the factors in its considerations in downgrading Australia's credit rating was the industrial and labour market rigidities. Of course this was anything but the major factor involved in its decision-making, as it made clear that a major factor involved, indeed the fundamental factor, was that we had an enormous balance of payments problem, which again can be said to be something which goes back to the neglect of the previous Government.

We have a system of virtually Third World-type exports because the previous Government was quite happy in the post-war period to allow this country to rely almost totally on rural products and later on minerals, which required very little in the way of productive effort or reliance on the skills of our work force. The previous Government allowed us to develop that pattern of exports, which meant that we were utterly dependent on commodity prices. When those commodity prices fell, as they have in the last year and a half, of course this nation was pushed into diabolical trouble because of a massive decline in terms of trade. If we had had a government which, through the post-war period, had developed strong manufacturing industries, internationally competitive manufacturing industries, had addressed work practices, addressed protection, addressed the structure of industry, and which had developed an efficient manufacturing industry, we would not have had the balance of payments problem we now have because a much lesser proportion of our exports would have been taken up by commodities and a much higher proportion, as is the case with most other developed countries, would have come from manufactured goods and services. However, we do not have their situation because the previous Government totally neglected to develop an efficient manufacturing industry and internationally competitive services. It has taken this Government to try to introduce the policies which will make those industries more efficient, to introduce the underlying macroeconomic situation which will create the international competitiveness, which it has done in relation to its wages policies, which have been eminently successful compared with anything which operated under the previous Government. This Government has introduced specific industry policies designed to make industries more efficient.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also referred in support of his case to Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, who was, for many years, Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and a leading figure in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He is a very respected figure in the trade union movement.

Indeed, he was so respected that when we came to office and saw the need for a very substantial revision of our industrial relations system, we established a committee of review of which he was a member. Mr Fitzgibbon was a member of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. Mr Fitzgibbon, as a member of the Hancock Committee, has made clear what he believes needs to be done to reform the industrial relations structure in this country. The report to which he was a signatory is the basis of wide-ranging changes to our industrial relations system which will be introduced by this Government by the end of this year. Those wide-ranging changes to our industrial relations structure will be very important changes indeed, but they will not be of the kind that the Opposition would want because we do not live in the fairyland in which the Opposition lives. People such as Mr Fitzgibbon are not going around this country saying: `We need to scrap or totally emasculate the arbitration system-in the way the Opposition would'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor have we. We have not said that. What nonsense.
—The honourable member said that he would emasculate it.
—What rot.

—The honourable member implied that he would emasculate it most severely. He said that he would take actions which would destroy it. If that is not what emasculation means, perhaps the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ought to study his dictionary.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence. He should hear the Minister in silence.
—There are no Labor people here to make a noise.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Moreton. He was asked to remain silent earlier. I now warn him.

—As I was saying, we will introduce wide-ranging changes to the industrial relations system. Those changes will be profound and important, and they will enable this country to have a more efficient industrial relations system in the future, one which will build on the enormous record which this Government has already achieved in industrial relations. This Government has presided over a period in which there has been a dramatic reduction in the level of industrial disputation, a dramatic reduction from what the previous Government could achieve in decades in office when it puddled around with an inefficient economy, totally unable to produce a relatively respectable level of industrial disputation. It took this Government's election to office to bring about a dramatic reduction in industrial disputation. We are certainly not complacent about that reduction; we are seeking to improve on that record. Our record is particularly impressive given the fact that it was put together in a period of very strong economic growth-a time which would, if one looks at the years of Liberal governments, normally see high levels of industrial disputation. In fact, we produced the opposite. Also, as the Prime Minister said in Question Time today, with the reduction in industrial disputation we have had a reduction in real wages of about 5 per cent during three years of strong economic growth. That never looked like being achieved under previous governments, when strong periods of economic growth always meant rising real wages.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have to say in any way that we are ashamed of our industrial relations policy. Our industrial relations policy of the past three years has been highly successful by the standards not only of the previous Government but of any government in the Western world, particularly if one looks at our wages outcome and the context in which that was achieved. We reject this matter of public importance. It is absurd to say that the Government's approach is belated and inadequate. The conference to be held on Wednesday in Melbourne will be a substantial step towards enabling us to eliminate restrictive work practices in this country. It is being welcomed by all parties-by the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The conference will not be just some pointless talkfest; rather, it is recognised by all parties to be a very important step towards our taking further measures to eliminate restrictive work practices in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The record that this Hawke Government is building is littered with indecision, U-turns and broken promises. As the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) so eloquently has said today, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has undergone a death-bed conversion-a conversion from arguing vehemently for excessive wage demands and often ludicrous work conditions to calling for restrictive work practices to be removed. It is not the managers of companies to whom the term `economic lunatics' applies; it is to the Hawke Government. The record stands to show that that is the case.

The coalition published its industrial relations policy in May this year. It addressed the rigidities of the labour market and the inflexibility of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-a Commission that could well be described by many employers as the humiliation and arbitration commission, because it so often caves in to big union pressure. It has humiliated employers, particularly small businesses, to the point where many have closed because of totally ludicrous on-cost wage structures.

Not only did the coalition recognise months ago that the rigid and strait-jacket approach to industrial relations matters had to go, but also so did most industry associations. We have already heard what Moody's Investor Services Inc. said about Australia when it downgraded our AAA credit rating. The Government has hung on to an 80-year-old industrial relations structure that is now outdated. It has done so because it wants to protect the big power blocks and the officials of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Those officials want to maintain a forum which they have corrupted and twisted to serve their own ends. That is why they want to maintain the system.

Now let us look at some of the costs and practices that have grown up-not just happened, but have been argued for, demanded and supported in the past by people such as the Prime Minister. When the Minister at the table talks about what coalition governments have done over the last 30 years, he should remember who was the head of the ACTU when the biggest outburst in these sorts of things occurred. We all know who that was; it was the Prime Minister of Australia and he is now suffering the consequences of what he vehemently argued for in the 1970s.

Let us take just one particular example of the National Building Trades Award. It is very interesting to look at the additional costs under that award. I will run through them. The annual leave entitlement is four weeks; sick leave, two weeks; public holidays, two weeks; the effect of smokos, two weeks; and idle wet weather time, four weeks. The total is 14 weeks. That means that in Australia there is 38 weeks of work for 52 weeks of pay. That is not all. There are additional costs on top of wages that employers have to pay under that award. The annual leave loading of 17 1/2 per cent is equivalent to 0.7 week's wages; long service leave is equivalent to 1.04 weeks' wages; payroll tax is equivalent to 3.17 weeks' wages and workers' compensation is equivalent to 14.85 weeks' wages. As the honourable member has said, we could go on and add the fringe benefits tax and other things, but the total is 19.76 weeks. Many of these on-costs occurred when the ACTU was led by Bob Hawke, the now Prime Minister of Australia. The result is that for every 1.9 weeks costs there is only one week worked. That is what the employers are faced with and it is no wonder that Australia is not competitive. When these imposts were fought for so stridently and vehemently with the blunt use of radical trade union power, as I have said before, the Prime Minister was the President of the ACTU. Now that he is on the receiving end of the outcomes of those practices, along with many others, he has the audacity to orchestrate the agenda of the coming work practices summit to include management practices. The question must be asked: Who is responsible for the management of our private companies? Heaven forbid that a government, of any political persuasion, should meddle with the management of the private sector of this economy, let alone the Hawke Government. Do honourable members remember Bourke's store and ACTU-Solo? I wonder what management skills were used there. Yet this Government has the audacity to talk of drones, lunatics, troglodytes and management practices. The Government must be joking, naive or foolish; most likely all three.

The Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry has stated that he does not understand what is meant by the need to improve management practices and he has quite logically clarified that management does not enter into the question of work practices. Management is about producing more wealth and greater productivity, whereas restrictive work practices are debilitating and impede productivity and greater wealth. Management must be allowed to manage. As mentioned already in this debate, restrictive work practices are legion. In August a telex, printed in the Australian, highlighted some of those restrictive work practices. I will outline a few of those work prcatices that were mentioned. This helps to focus on this issue, which has been raised by people such as Stan Wallis, a spokesman for the Business Council of Australia, and by Peko-Wallsend Ltd. It stated:
For some unions a general foreman cannot directly pass an instruction to an employee.
In other words, the foreman cannot have direct control over the people for whom he is responsible. It went on:
Instructions must go through the leading hand, who is elected by his workmates. The chosen leading hand may not be the most competent person for the job.
Another illustration of restrictive work practices is:

Dust suppression on roads is undertaken by watering. The unions insist that the water trucks operate even when it is raining. The unions have also refused to allow the company to introduce dust suppression agents commonly used throughout the industry to reduce watering and improve road surfaces.
Two persons must be employed for each piece of mobile equipment used on stockpiles in the port area. One person operates the machine while the other rests-
I guess he has a good sleep while he is waiting on the job-
They change over every 2 hours.

The future for Australia to have a dynamic, internationally competitive and responsive economy lies in harnessing the human resources of employees and employers. These resources include creativity, inventiveness, motivation, entrepreneurial vision, skill, knowledge and a desire to better family lifestyles. It is going to be the coalition's handling of the industrial relations area that will put those things into practice in this great country of ours.

Business enterprises centred around families must be given a greater opportunity to participate meaningfully with their employees and to develop legally binding agreements that meet the unique needs of each enterprise. It is time for Australia to meet the challenge of the future by moving gradually but steadily towards a system that gives greater control of industrial matters to employees and employers at the enterprise level, and which enhances the removal of restrictive work practices. It is sad for Australia that the Hawke Labor Government has had to be prodded, pushed and dragged by the neck to recognise the debilitating nature of the hundreds of work practices in this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW WHARF AND SEAMANSHIP SCHOOL AT HMAS CERBERUS, CRIB POINT, VICTORIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

The Labor Party's great envy spasm, which does not seem to extend to the collection of First Empire clocks, does extend to the purchase, apparently, of BMW and other motor vehicles. The envy principle overcomes economic common sense. The motor industries employ many people. They are experiencing extraordinarily great difficulty at the moment. Because of the failure of the economic policies of the Hawke Government there has been a 40 per cent depreciation of the Australian dollar on the trade weighted index, and over a 50 per cent depreciation of the Australian dollar against the Japanese yen. This has had a devastating effect on the motor car industry. I refer not only to fully imported cars but also to the domestic industry, because a lot of components are imported.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, because of the tariff walls, the domestic industry puts its prices up to get closer to the imported car prices. So here we have an industry which is reeling because of the heavy depreciation of the Australian dollar, increased sale prices, an earlier increase in sales tax of about one per cent last year, the introduction of lead free petrol engines and, of course, the notorious fringe benefits tax, which had a devastating effect on the motor industry. The Premier of South Australia-a Labor Premier-made personal representations to this Government in order to try to have the fringe benefits tax on motor cars withdrawn because of the devastating effects it would have on the motor industry in his State. So here we have yet another industry that has been devastated by a whole series of government decisions. The Government is now loading an additional impost at the top end of the market-which still employs people in Australia-because of the overall envy principle which is present within the Labor Party.
The final area affecting industry that I want to mention is the imposition of tax on computer software. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech stated:

Avoidance of sales tax occurs through the device of selling only the discs and tapes on which computer software is embodied and licensing the consumer to use the software itself; sales tax is then payable only on the value of the discs, which is a small fraction of the total price.

So the sales tax law is to be amended to include the value of the software for tax purposes in the assessment of tax. That is all very well, but this will raise an extra $80m in tax from business during this financial year. As can be seen from the revenue estimates, it is a substantial item. It will have a substantial impact on business. It will also affect the technological development of new software in Australia. Software can be a significant business cost. For example, the price of an accounting package ranges from about $3,000 to $35,000 and beyond. Some software can cost over $100,000. So an extra 20 per cent represents a substantial price increase. Of course, it is an increase in the price of the inputs into export-competing businesses in Australia. Therefore, it cannot be overlooked.

The overall issue is that this Budget contains measures which will collect an extra $358m in wholesale sales tax. In the package which was announced on 19 September last year an additional $110m in wholesale sales tax was added. So nearly half a billion dollars in extra wholesale sales tax will be collected-a tax which the Treasurer said was a bad tax. That is really what we are facing up to. The taxation White Paper which was issued before the National Taxation Summit last year states:

The existing wholesale sales tax is a narrowly-based tax which applies only to selected consumption goods and some intermediate goods. It does not cover any services, and it has many anomalies and inconsistencies . . . Its lack of comprehensiveness in coverage, and its multiple tax rate structure, lead to a number of problems . . .
There appears a full page of problems concerning wholesale sales tax that the Treasurer has outlined in his paper. Later, he states:
The inherent and introduced limitations of the wholesale sales tax constitute strong arguments for its replacement by a new broad-based tax.
At the National Taxation Summit the Treasurer followed up this theme by saying :
There was a strong theme, nevertheless, that option A-
that is the terrible package that has been introduced-
could fully meet our tax reform objectives . . .
We certainly agree with that. The Treasurer also said:
The Government believes the optimum route is to shift the huge preponderant dependency upon the income tax system to a base in consumption.
That is what he said in his speech to the Taxation Summit in July 1985. There was a lot of discussion on these proposals. Towards the end of the discussion the Treasurer said:

It has to be understood that by cutting out the broad-based consumption tax we cut out the heart of the package and with it the opportunity for significant increases in benefits and reductions in tax rates . . . There is no getting away from the fact that whatever proves to be feasible in the income tax base broadening, it is only by broadening the indirect tax that really substantial changes can be made.

We all know what the outcome was. The Treasurer failed in his attempt to get the Government to agree to a broadly based indirect tax. He was lumbered with the wholesale sales tax. Following that, he introduced an increase in that wholesale sales tax-in his own words, this thoroughly unsatisfactory tax-of $110m. Now it has been further increased by $358m-a total of $468m. Of course, this adds about half a percentage point to inflation. The fundamental failure and the fundamental reason why he is having to do this at this stage is that the Government has simply failed to cut expenditure in any meaningful way.

The Prime Minister is quite correct. Taxation will be a major issue in the next election. There is a need to reduce the top marginal rates of income tax. There is a need to extend the indirect tax base. There is a need to remove the anti-business and anti-investment taxes that have been introduced by this Government-the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, and all those other taxes that have reduced the capacity of Australian industry to invest. But the first and prime requirement for doing those things is to make substantial reductions in government expenditure. That is something that this Government, the highest taxing government in Australia's history, has failed signally to do. Indeed, it has even broken its most recent promise-the tax trilogy promise-by increasing taxes above its trilogy commitment by $1,400m a year. That is yet another failure on the Government's part to meet its commitment to the Australian people. I shall summarise the position because I do not wish to take any more time. I am aware that my colleagues wish to talk about the specific industries that will be affected by these measures.

We do not like the Bill, which does not follow the priorities that we would follow in office. We deplore the Bill's effect on the industries that will suffer under its provisions, especially the wine industry, the citrus growers, the dairy industry, the motor industry and the computer software industry. These are the main industries that will be hit by this measure. We shall not, however, be collaborating with the Australian Democrats to try to amend or reject the Bill in the Senate. As an Opposition we can, with the Democrats, widen the Budget deficit by knocking off tax measures, but we cannot close it by reducing expenditures. Only a government can do that, not an Opposition. For that reason, and that reason alone, we shall not be opposing these particular measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill imposes an increase in the sales tax which applies to wines and other products produced from grapes. I would have expected an overflowing gallery in the National Party corner of the chamber, and I am amazed that not one National Party member has come in to listen to the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). SPEECH.PARA: If ever we wanted to know whether the shadow Treasurer was a wimp, the answer has been given to us by his speech this afternoon. He wrung his hands and said that the Opposition does not like sales tax measures but it will not oppose them. He then proceeded to give us 15 minutes of bellyaching about why he was against each of the measures which the Government has introduced in sales tax Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable member a wimp or not?
—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo will remain silent.

—I tend to agree with the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in a recent Four Corners program, when he said that as far as he is concerned, wimps are out. That is my attitude on this as well. It really comes back to the Opposition trying to play politics on the tax debate. SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) said earlier, if the Liberal Party ever forms a government we shall be left wondering whether it will have any taxes at all. The honourable member for Mackellar said that the measures before us would raise $358m in a full year. I am not quite sure where he gets that figure. It is stated in the explanatory memorandum, which covers the three Bills, that a net revenue gain of $249m would be derived in a full year. There is some confusion there and perhaps the next Opposition speaker or a later speaker in this debate could examine the inconsistency. In any event, I hope that an Opposition speaker will examine the inconsistency and advise the House how the Opposition has come up with $358m.

It is important to remember what the sales tax regime was when the Liberal-National Party went out of government. We know that it was a total mess. We had various rates: 0 per cent, 7 1/2 per cent, 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 32 1/2 per cent. We had the famous Kit-Kat problem; no one knew whether a Kit-Kat should be taxed or not. A Kit-Kat was considered to be a piece of confectionary yet an almost identical chocolate wafer biscuit was considered to be food and exempt from sales tax. I applaud the measures which the Treasurer introduced last year which tidied up the sales tax regime. We now have only 0 per cent, 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. This system is much simpler and it cuts the costs of administering the sales tax regime.

I should like now to address one of the more controversial matters in this legislation, which is the proposal to increase sales tax on the wholesale prices of alcoholic wine and cider from the current 10 per cent to 20 per cent. As many honourable members will be aware, there is heavy discrimination in the level of taxation that is currently applied to beer and spirits. There is an excise of 76c per litre on beer and more than $23 per litre of alcohol on spirits. In many ways wine is treated favourably in comparison with beer and spirits. The average Australian tends to drink more beer than wine-I accept that that is changing-and the concessional rate that applies to wine drinkers tends to favour those on higher incomes.

Two years ago, many of the grape growers suggested the Government's decision to impose a 10 per cent sales tax on wine would put the entire industry out of business. That has been shown to be a total exaggeration. The problems of the industry are the result of competition from imports, particularly from Europe, from where, in my view, wine has been dumped on the Australian market. The devaluation of the Australian dollar will, I think, make a very significant contribution towards cutting back the level of imports of wine into Australia. I am sure the Government will keep this measure under review in the coming years to ensure that there will be no significant disruption to the industry.

Some members of the Opposition have suggested that it is wrong for the Government to impose a 10 per cent sales tax on the wholesale price of flavoured milk. We should remember that the main competitors in the milk bars for flavoured and sweetened milk are things which are already subject to sales tax. Carbonated soft drinks-such as Coca Cola and Pepsi Cola and all the other things that do wonders for teeth-are subject to a 20 per cent rate of sales tax. Under this Bill Australian fruit juice drinks will also be subject to a 10 per cent sales tax. In comparison, if any school children drink packaged unflavoured milk-that is the real milk that is better for them-they will still pay no sales tax on that. I can see that there is a lot of support for that in the House this afternoon. I suppose we could expect some members of the Opposition to argue that we should not tax flavoured milk because children drink it and that we should not apply sales tax to anything which children purchase. The question then arises: Does the Opposition intend to abolish the current sales tax on soft drinks and on confectionery? Of course, it will not. We have to remember that a lot of adults, including myself sometimes, purchase flavoured milk, so it is simply illogical for the Opposition to argue that the 10 per cent sales tax on flavoured milk hits children. The Opposition could use the argument with cigarettes. Does the Opposition say that because some children purchase cigarettes we should abolish all taxes on cigarettes?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they are saying; that is their logic.

—As the honourable member for Bendigo suggests, that is the logic of the arguments the Opposition is putting forward today. Another measure in this Bill which has my very strong support is the proposal to increase sales tax on luxury motor vehicles. It applies only to vehicles with a retail price of more than approximately $29,500. I listened to the bellyaching of the honourable member for Mackellar who said it would cause great disruption to the industry. As far as I am aware the industry does not manufacture and assemble Volvos, BMWs and Mercedes-Benz in Australia and if someone decides to buy an Australian car, which is cheaper, in preference to a Mercedes or a BMW--
—And better!

—Not only does he get a better car, as the honourable member for Charlton suggests, but he will get a car which is assembled with more Australian labour and more Australian parts manufactured by Australian small businesses. So I think that is something which deserves the unanimous support of this chamber. On top of that I suppose some people could argue that those who currently own luxury motor vehicles have actually received a bonus from this Government because the second hand value of those existing Mercedes and BMWs will have actually increased. Because of the generous exemptions in the capital gains tax legislation of this Government they have just received a special tax free bonus. The important thing to remember is that we had to raise a certain amount of money through these sales tax measures and by imposing this increase in sales tax only on the luxury car market we will hit those with the greatest capacity to pay, and that is why this measure has the support of this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I was totally unable to understand the views of the honourable member for Mackellar on the new measures to tax computer software. This Government is introducing a measure which will smash a current tax avoidance scheme and the Opposition is saying that while Opposition members will not vote against the measure-they do not want to have their names recorded as voting against it-they will oppose it in their speeches and bellyache about it. In fact the current sales tax avoidance scheme means that sales tax is being collected only on the monetary value of the medium of the computer software. So if a person purchases a computer disk or a cassette tape with that software on it, the company provides the purchaser with a licence to use the software and sales tax is levied only on the value of the cassette or disk; and that is nowhere near the true market value of the computer software. Most of the value of the computer software is the research and development which has gone into preparing the program, its debugging and testing, and the final production. Yet the Opposition claims that this is a substantial impost on small business. I do not consider IBM Australia Ltd, Digital Equipment Corporation (Australia) Pty Ltd and NEC Australia Pty Ltd to be classified as small businesses, and I certainly think this measure is very worthwhile. It is important to note that computer software which is used in-house or which is available for export will be exempt from this new computer sales tax measure.

Another important measure in this Bill, which has not had a lot of publicity, is the current exemption for the purchase of computers, calculators and other scientific instruments by people such as teachers at schools, lecturers at universities and students. This exemption was granted because of an association with some teaching institution. That is to be abolished, and I support that measure. We are still allowing purchases by the institutions concerned-universities and schools-to be exempt. But as every honourable member in this chamber should know, any teacher or lecturer at a university can make arrangements with particular retailers of computer equipment. In effect any teacher or lecturer does not have to pay sales tax on any computers or calculators which they purchase. I think that is unfair to the rest of the community, who have to pay a higher rate of tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —They used to buy colour television sets like that, too.

—As the honourable member for Bendigo suggests, they used to use that lurk to purchase colour television sets, but I understand action was taken to make sure that that no longer applies. I wholeheartedly support the measures which have been brought into the chamber today. It is interesting that while the Opposition does not have the courage and the guts to vote against the measure it will use the rest of the debate today to try to take cheap shots at what is an excellent piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wondered whether during this debate any member of the Australian Labor Party would show any sensitivity whatsoever to what the Government is doing by bringing in some of these measures. On Budget night all that was said about the doubling of the tax on wine was that it would reduce the heavy taxation discrimination against beer and spirit drinkers in favour of wine. The rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider is to be increased from 10 per cent to the standard sales tax rates of 20 per cent. This is expected to increase revenue by 47 per cent. When the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) introduced the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Amendment Bill, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the comments already made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech . . . I will do no more than outline briefly the changes proposed.
He then went on to say:
Firstly, the rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar fermented alcoholic beverages is to be increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent.

I thought some honourable members might give a little more of an explanation or rationale in this debate about these new taxes, particularly those on the wine industry, to demonstrate why, other than for those reasons of some sort of parity with beer-I will go into that a little later-they disagree with the legislation. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has given us a very sketchy look at that. I know that time in this debate is very limited. Some of the other measures, particularly the introduction of sales tax on fruit and vegetable juices and the dairy industry, will bear down very heavily on those industries which are in economic difficulty already. I know other speakers on my side of the Parliament will be enlarging on those areas, and I particularly want to talk about the wine industry.

The Government has introduced a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on wine. The wine industry did not pay any sales tax two and a half years ago. The new taxes have come at a time when the industry is suffering from structural change and when grape growers returns are at a record low level. The average real wine grape price has fallen by 30 per cent since 1983. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has predicted that grape growers in certain areas of Australia will have a negative income next year of some $700. There is no doubt that the low rate of returns, particularly for grape growers, is a significant problem facing the industry.

What Australia needs at this time is a government prepared to handle the situation with extreme sensitivity. We need to reduce overall production; we need a concerted national program to buy Australian products and find new export markets; we need a uniform code of wine standards; and we need the prompt introduction of plant variety rights. Instead, the Government has ignored the McKay report of the Inquiry into the Grape and Wine Industries and advice from the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association Inc. and has taken action which can only be regarded as traitorous. In the 1984-85 Budget the Government stated that it would gain an additional $62m from a 10 per cent tax on wine and cider. This year an additional $47m will be extracted from the wine industry. That means about $109m will be taxed from the industry this year. The McKay report said that there should be no increase in the sales tax until sufficient time had gone by to measure the impact of the present tax. Sufficient time has gone by to measure the impact of the tax, and it has been disastrous. The 10 per cent sales tax arising out of the 1984 Budget was largely absorbed by wine producers and retailers in an effort to maintain wine sales. Consumer price index figures prove that. During the period August 1984 to December 1985 wine prices rose an average of 6.3 per cent while the CPI, on all goods, rose by 11.2 per cent. Remember that at the same time a 10 per cent sales tax had been imposed.

It may surprise many Australians that Australia is now a net wine importer, so while our premium wines are sitting on the shelves Australians are ripping off themselves by purchasing inferior expensive imports. The House may be interested to know that as recently as 1980-81 Australians imported and exported an equivalent litreage of wine. The very recent trend is an increase in our imports and a decrease in our exports, and the new wine tax has helped this disastrous trend. In value terms last year, Australia imported $51.3m worth of wine while our exports languished to $20m. There has been an encouraging upturn in the last few months, but we must remember that we are exporting only some 3 to 4 per cent of our whole production.

Since the turn of the century Australia has been a net exporter of wines. Our golden years were 1925-40 when our annual exports averaged well over 15 million litres. Last year we managed to export only 8.75 million litres. I realise that wine exports are exempt from sales tax, but the Government must understand that it has driven down the domestic industry to such a level that wine companies are restricted in simple budgetary terms to pursuing new wine markets or developing different products. One cannot starve an industry of funds and then tell it to find new markets and develop new products. Exporters of today export at a very marginal rate. It is not as though we can say: `Okay, we are exporting $20 million-worth'. Maybe it costs our exporters about that to sell their wine overseas.

While the Federal Government is extracting $120m annually out of the wine industry it has condescended to return $5.3m in terms of a very limited grape pull scheme. I guess that is good arithmetic for the Government but it is pretty lousy arithmetic for the wine producers. Obviously, the Government recognises the plight of the industry as it is involved in a grape pull scheme of that magnitude. All of this comes on top of the disallowance of entertainment expenses, which has had a marked effect on our premium wine producers.

The depreciation of the dollar has caused a significant rise in the cost of bottles, corks, oak casks and many other items which, of necessity, are imported. The industry has had to put up with the extraordinary vacillations of this Government trying to make up its mind on grape spirit excise. The first Hawke Budget introduced an excise of $2.61 per litre of alcohol used for wine fortification. This was very destabilising, and it was not until there was a 50 per cent reduction in the production of grape spirit that the Government came to its senses and cancelled the tax. That was not the first time that Labor governments have introduced a tax and had to repeal it before it destroyed the wine industry. One can go back to the Scullin Government in the 1930s, which introduced a general sales tax of 2.5 per cent and, after a decline in white wine sales, the tax was removed. I regret that the next lesson was learned by the coalition Government when an excise of 50c per gallon was introduced in 1970. Two years later that excise was abolished as wine sales took a sharp decline.

In short, the wine industry is very susceptible to changes in cost. It is what economists call an elastic commodity-low prices lead to consumption and higher prices lead to the purchase of alternative beverages. Historical evidence makes it quite obvious that high taxation can destroy this industry. As I said earlier, the wine industry throughout Australia has suffered a series of problems and about 80 per cent of those problems could have been solved if the Government had handled its policy in this area with more sensitivity.

In my electorate and in the adjacent areas of Mount Barker and the Frankland River are well over 70 producing wineries. The emphasis is on the production of premium quality wines. Generally, the wineries have been financed and then subsequently supported by non-farm income. The area has been rapidly developing since the late 1960s and many wineries, in strict economic terms, have been overcapitalised and, hence, the return on capital is very low. The wineries have not had time to consolidate. These areas produce about 5,500 tonnes of grapes, and that is about one per cent of total Australian production. But that one per cent represents some of the highest quality wines produced in Australia. The Forrest region alone would employ some 350 people directly in making wine but many more would be employed in the related industries of service-retailing and tourism. One can multiply that figure to appreciate the number of people who would be so employed throughout the nation.

It has been the premium quality wines from overseas that have made the inroads on the Australian market. Overall it is only about 5 per cent of our production but it is about 17 per cent of bottled premium wine. What the Government is doing with this 20 per cent wine tax is to threaten the viability of the most susceptible end of the wine market, that is, the premium wines of Australia. Many will argue about which end of the market this tax will hurt the most. Those in the greatest difficulty would probably be in the Riverland and other parts of what may be called the lower end of the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sunraysia.

—Sunraysia and the irrigation areas which are more concerned with bulk production and which were in extreme difficulties before this tax was considered. It is irrelevant that the 20 per cent sales tax is not paid on exports. If our wineries cannot survive on the domestic market with this new cost imposition, there would be no one left to do the exporting. While the combined Federal and State taxes act like an engorged parasite on the back of the wine industry, it will never be able to reverse our wine trade imbalance; it will be financially too weak. Currently, through State liquor taxes and the Federal Government's wholesale tax, combined governments will take $217m out of gross liquor sales of some $550m, leaving company profits-honourable members should listen to this-of $20m to $30m. That is a tax-profit ratio for the wine industry of some 8 : 1, yet we are trying to compare the wine industry with the beer industry. There are 400 different wineries, 6,000-odd different producers and thousands of people who are involved in this industry on a regional basis, yet the overall profit of wineries is some $25m to $30m. That must be compared with that of the beer industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently we heard about one beer baron who intends spending $10m on advertising-equivalent to one third of the profit of the whole wine industry. The industries just do not relate. This is a regional industry. As I said, 6,000-odd people are directly employed, there are 400-odd wineries, and there are massive problems with over-supply. There is no justification for this measure.

I have extended my time a little and I apologise to my colleagues. I wind up by saying that this level of taxation is primarily responsible for our wine trade demise and imbalance. It is a disgustingly high level of taxation. It is a further tax on Australia's productive sector. After the money has gone through the Government's administrative mangle we can be sure that it will be redistributed to the totally non-productive and non-job producing sector. I appeal to this Government, as I have to previous Labor governments, to repeal this tax before it does any more damage.
