DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986SALES TAX ACTS AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax Acts Amendment Bill increase sales taxes on a broad range of household appliances, gardening and industrial tools, computers, sound recordings and videos, wine and cider. A number of new items never before taxed will have sales tax levied on them by this Government. As my coalition colleagues participating in this debate will discuss the full impact of this legislation, I intend to contain my remarks to the tax on wine, fruit juice and flavoured milk. I should emphasise that this debate is being conducted not in an atmosphere of major tax reform-that is, broadly based indirect taxation with low personal tax rates-but at a time when overall government taxes are the highest ever.

SPEECH.PARA: In our economic climate, which demands tax relief and incentive but which is getting from this Government an insatiable demand for revenue to reduce the size of the deficit, the Budget deficit should be cut by public expenditure restraint. It is inconceivable that the rural industries of dairying, viticulture and citrus growing should be further penalised at a time when domestic cost burdens are intolerable, interest rates are rising and the debt structure of these three industries is at its highest ever. This legislation does just this. The rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar fermented alcoholic beverages is being increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Certain presently exempt non-alcoholic beverages are to be taxed at the 10 per cent rate. These include flavoured milk, non-alcoholic wine and cider and similar beverages and, broadly, all non-carbonated fruit juice products containing not less than 25 per cent by volume of Australian fruit juice.

The Australian wine industry comprises almost 7,000 growers and numerous diverse and competent wine makers. Our wine industry is part of our national culture and way of life, and should be supported. Two successive Australian Labor Party government imposts-first, a 10 per cent tax and now an increase of that tax to 20 per cent-are putting this industry at risk. Many grape growers and a number of wine makers will not survive the next 12 months. This measure will cost the industry another $109m in a full year. There will be a further erosion of domestic sales.

Exports of Australian wine increased by 24.7 per cent in 1985-86, and were worth $205m, and could have been expected to continue their market consolidation. The competitiveness of those exports has now been further undermined. It is inappropriate to increase the sales tax on wine or coolers while a large degree of structural adjustment is occurring in the grape growing industry. An illustration of this is the fact that the area of grapevines not yet bearing in South Australia has almost halved in the last three years, reducing from 2,179 hectares in 1982-83 to 1,231 hectares in 1985-86. Of course similar figures can be shown for other producing regions.

Unlike industries producing other alcoholic beverages, the grape and wine industries are major contributors to the economies of rural communities. The Government does not appreciate the relationship between and the dependence upon each sector. This measure will drive more producers into the dried fruit area. This point was well made in Mildura last week at an Industries Assistance Commission hearing into the citrus industry. Henry Tankard, Chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Association, said that social and political upheaval will occur if dried fruit downturns coincide with downturns in the citrus industry. That is exactly what is happening. However, we should also remember that 70 per cent of all grapes used by the wine industry do not have any other use. Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures show that the average real return to wine grape growers has been negative for four of the last five years and is estimated to be even worse in 1986-87, with average farm income on family farms being reduced to minus $700 per farm. This is a disastrous figure and the doubling of the tax on wine will only increase the problem facing grape growers and the communities in which they live.

The nature of the wine and grape industries is such that rapid adjustments cannot be made following changes in government policy. This has been noted by both the McKay Inquiry into the Grape and Wine Industries and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade.

The effect of the 1984 sales taxes is slowly becoming clearer and its severity on grape growers is apparent from the response to the vine pull scheme. This untimely additional tax can only add to the welfare costs of government in, and reduce the revenue from, the rural economies. There is a desperate need to look at a number of related issues to assist the wine industry-for instance, the method of taxation of wine producing stocks; tax charges on brandy, including imported produce; the interrelationship between the wine and brandy industries; quality controls and labelling requirements, and their application to imported products; wine promotion arrangements, with particular emphasis on export, which should be given incentive and encouragement; and the continuing issue of the research and development of new products and industry methods. This new tax was the last thing that should have been introduced at this time.

I turn now to citrus imports. These will increase the retail price of fruit juice products, which will result in reduced consumer sales in the present difficult economic circumstances. It will reduce by 50 per cent the incentive for manufacturers to use Australian fruit juices in their products, particularly fruit juice drinks and fruit juice cordials. The decision could encourage manufacturers to increase their use of cheaper imported juices and to pay the 20 per cent sales tax in preference to using Australian fruit juices and, in this case, to pay a 10 per cent tax. This will have a dramatic effect on the navel juice and lemon juice sectors of the industry, where there is a large usage of the products in drinks and cordials. This will result in a loss of fruit sales by growers and reduced employment in the industry. As the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) said, this is a disgraceful decision, and it is a further blow to citrus processors who are already suffering hardship in the current season due to the collapse of world orange juice prices and the dramatic fall in incomes from both processing markets and domestic fresh fruit markets.

The average income on a citrus property last season was $51,000. The average cost was $66,535, which left a deficit on the average citrus growing property of $15,478. Citrus production and its viability are important. It is important to the Sunraysia and Murray Valley regions of my electorate and the electorate of my colleague, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). It is essential to the electorate of my colleague from Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), where 30 per cent of farm output in the Murrumbidgee irrigation area comes from the citrus industry. There, as in other horticultural areas, cash flows are badly depressed. Like the tax on wine, this tax has been introduced at a time when an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry is taking place and when there has been an abrupt drop in prices of concentrate citrus from $1,800 a tonne to $800 a tonne in a few months. I am quite sure that even honourable members in government would understand that no one can suffer a drop in the price paid for a product in such a short period of time and survive.

It is ridiculous that Brazil, with its extremely low wage structure and subsidised industry, should be permitted to ruin our industry. It is even more ridiculous that Brazil should have developing nation preferential tariff entry concessions into Australia. Citrus is unfairly penalised in a number of ways. Imports of Californian citrus come into this country while our products are kept out of the United States of America due to dubious quarantine requirements in relation to septoria spot. Surely the prevalent canker in the United States is a greater threat to our industry. These unfair protective measures must be resolved. I also ask why our own supermarket chains show a greater commitment to imported Sunkist Californian citrus than to Australian grown products. I think this also requires investigation.

Time does not allow me to speak about flavoured milk, but I warn the Government that, in relation to the 10 per cent tax imposed on flavoured milk, the same argument applies in the dairy industry as it does to the tax imposed on the wine and citrus industries. Communities are dependent upon our irrigated horticultural industries. They are probably the most successful examples of regional development in this country but today they are all in trouble at the one time. As the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) has said, the cumulative result of this will be disastrous. These industries are nationally important. They are efficient industries. The protection that is provided to the citrus industry in Australia is in the vicinity of about $33 a tonne. In the United States it is $58 a tonne and in Japan it is $120 a tonne. These are all industries that are capable of export and foreign exchange earnings. Other major nations are dramatically deserting their idealistic free trade policies, and we in Australia are the suckers. Our nation's critical economic position demands that we apprise this policy until the world is ready to reciprocate. We are also left in a declining competitive position. We have industries here of an extremely high labour content and the multiplier effect is unusually high. Our nation's labour costs, comparative with our competitors, are impossibly high.

As I have said, these are industries of exceptionally high decentralisation and environmental value. Entire regional communities are suffering hardship as a direct result of Labor's taxes and charges. I remind the House again of taxes other than these-the fringe benefits tax, the assets test, the capital gains tax and, as far as the wine industry is concerned, the entertainment tax. There is no justification for these taxes and I am surprised that no member of the Labor Party who represents a wine growing area, such as the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) or the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), are speaking on these Bills. I wonder why they are not speaking on these Bills. I suggest that they are not in the House because they are probably hiding in an empty wine cellar in their particular electorates. While they may be getting paid at this moment for doing what is supposed to be their jobs, I can assure the House that at the next election the wine and citrus industries will ensure that they are unemployed. I am appalled that these honourable members justify these taxes in relation to the brewery industry when, as one of my colleagues has already said, last year the wine industry had a net profit of $30m while a number of the beer barons in the brewing industry spent more than that annually on their own advertising campaigns. There is absolutely no justification at all for these taxes and I am appalled that the Labor Party has introduced these new measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dubois Mr S.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1986 and the Sales Tax Acts Amendment Bill 1986 before the House today are an integral part of the Budget. They are part of the revenue raising measures. The Budget recognises the cut in our incomes which the rest of the world has imposed on Australia. This Budget adjusts our economic life to the harsh realities, however unpalatable they may seem. The domestic economy is sound. Our present difficulties are the result of decisions taken overseas and, therefore, beyond our control. It would be irresponsible of us to ignore the drop in our export income. We cannot go on spending more that we earn and still expect the rest of the world to continue lending money to us out of its savings so that we can continue to live beyond our means.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget addresses the problems facing Australia today. The Government has cut back to zero real growth in outlays. The deficit will be reduced to $3.5 billion. If we had not taken certain steps to rein in the deficit, it would have been somewhere in the order of $7.5 billion. It will now be less than half this amount. The Government has imposed on itself the most rigorous financial discipline in managing the economy. The Government had to increase some taxes while at the same time reduce its own spending.

The financial impact of the sales tax Bills before the House will be a net revenue gain of $196m in 1986-87 and $249m in a full year. The consumer price index will increase by less than 0.18 percentage points as a result of these measures. These adjustments to receipts and outlays will allow the Government to introduce the next phase of tax reforms-that of reductions to personal income tax rates. When this Government came to office it reduced the lowest marginal tax rate from 30c in the dollar to 25c in the dollar. That priority could not wait until more widespread changes were introduced. This rate will be further reduced to 24c in the dollar along with reductions to other marginal rates. The highest rates, currently a punitive 60c in the dollar, will be reduced to 49c and the 48c and 46c rates will be reduced to 40c. The threshold before tax is payable will be increased to $5,100 per annum. These substantial cuts will produce a fairer and more efficient tax system. For so long the pay as you earn taxpayer has borne the brunt of taxes while others have manipulated their financial affairs in such a way as to minimise their tax liability.

Additional sales tax revenue will come from increases on wines and alcoholic beverages, on luxury cars, on previously exempt non-alcoholic beverages and on correcting certain anomalies that have emerged in the levying of sales tax. Cars, station wagons, and four-wheel drive vehicles which retail for more than $29,649 will attract an increase in sales tax from the general rate to the luxury rate of 30 per cent. This amount of $29,646 is the present upper limit on which depreciation is allowable for income tax purposes and will be indexed each July. This increase in sales tax will redress the generous tax treatment still enjoyed by people who drive luxury imported cars. Despite the fringe benefits tax, these people still get a little help from the public purse in indulging themselves in this way. The majority of cars produced in Australia will not be affected as they retail for below $29,646.

TALK.START.PARA: —Workers' cars.

—Exactly. It will be the imported cars that will cost more because these measures, together with the effects of the changes in the exchange rate, will give Australian-made cars a further price advantage in the market-place. An increase in the rate of sales tax from 10 per cent to the general rate of 20 per cent has been imposed on alcoholic wines, ciders and similar fermented beverages. This will mean an increase in about 40c per cask of wine and of about 55c for a bottle of premium wine retailing for about $7. I agree with the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) that wines from the Frankland River district are amongst the finest in Australia. However, the small wine makers of Australia-admittedly there are many-tell me that the biggest threat they face is from the PLO. When I asked them who the PLO was they said it was the Penfolds, Lindemans and Orlandos of this world.
—Terrorists.

—Yes, indeed, financial terrorists. There is the view that wine should attract sales tax, that the industry should pay its own way. It is standing on its own two feet and there is no reason why it should continue to be exempt from sales tax. The long suffering beer drinker, who has been the mainstay of many Treasurers in the past, has not been affected in this Budget. These sales tax measures correct an anomaly that has allowed wine drinkers to pay tax-and only recently-at a lower rate than that of beer drinkers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also removes the exemption from sales tax for certain beverages and reclassifies them under the schedule that attracts a rate of 10 per cent. Packaged flavoured milk that contains not less than 95 per cent milk will be taxed at 10 per cent. This will result in about a 2.5c increase in a 300-millilitre carton of flavoured milk. If that flavoured milk contains less than 95 per cent milk, it will continue to be taxed at 20 per cent. Unflavoured milk and certain dry powder products will continue to be exempt from sales tax. Fruit juice and other Australian non-alcoholic wines and ciders will also be reclassified to the third schedule and attract a 10 per cent sales tax. The price of a two-litre pack of orange juice is expected to increase by about 23c as a result of these changes. Imported non-alcoholic wines and ciders will continue to be taxed at 20 per cent. Other soft drinks made in Australia, such as lemonade and carbonated beverages, are also currently taxed at 20 per cent. That type of beverage suffered a relative disadvantage when compared with fruit juice beverages.

Sales tax will be extended to developing photographs at the same 20 per cent rate currently applicable to prints. Swimming pools and associated equipment will also be taxed at the general rate. A 10 per cent rate will also apply to bathroom fittings, sinks, basins et cetera. These items will be treated the same as furniture, refrigerators, washing machines and other household goods. Other changes include the closure of certain loopholes, such as the tax free purchase of scientific instruments by students and teachers. The purchase of computers and calculators by universities and schools for their own use will continue to be exempt from sales tax. When these instruments are purchased by teachers and students for home use they will no longer be exempt from sales tax and sales tax will have to be paid.

These sales tax measures are both fair and equitable. They spread the tax burden to those items which should contribute, exemptions for which can no longer be justified. They remove anomalies that have crept into the system. These measures will generate the receipts needed to implement the greatest tax reform ever seen in Australia. When the income tax cuts are implemented in December this year and in July next year, the sales tax increases will be seen in their true perspective. It will become clear to the people of Australia that this Government is delivering on its promise of a better and fairer go for all Australians. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the 1983 election there was a period of economic growth in this country. However, that growth was not stimulated by the Government; it was brought about by the breaking of the drought. We were lucky enough to have a wages pause in place and the international economy was improving. Instead of encouraging the private sector to grow unhindered, the Hawke Labor Government set about a major expansion of both the size of government and government expenditure. Instead of fostering the productive private sector, the Government set about competing with the private sector for both funds and resources. That government action pushed up interest rates and the inflation rate. The Government was living on borrowed time and borrowed money. Now the chickens have come home to roost.

SPEECH.PARA: As the deficit has skyrocketed, together with the high inflation rate and higher interest rates, the international community has sold our dollar down. Let me give a couple of indications of our international competitive position. For example, at the moment Australia's short term interest rate is about 17 1/2 per cent. In Japan it is 4.7 per cent; in West Germany, 4.4 per cent and in the United States, 5.6 per cent. Under this Labor Government, labour costs have gone up by around 6.6 per cent. In Japan last year they went up by 2.2 per cent; in the United States by 2.4 per cent and in Canada by 2.6 per cent. No wonder we are facing such an economic crisis.

The Government has realised in more recent times that, as a result of its gross economic mismanagement in which it has squandered Australia's economic future, we as a nation can no longer go on with the mounting level of debt built up by its economic policies. By June next year Australia will be looking at a gross external debt in excess of $110 billion-nearly $7,000 per person. The message given by the public to the Government was that the way to get out of the problem was to reduce the size of government and government expenditure. Instead, the Government took an alternative route. It said: `No, the way we will get out of our problem is by increasing tax'. Tough decisions were needed but they were not taken. Axe, not tax, was the message from the community, but the Government could not make the hard decisions to cut expenditure. Instead, it moved to substantially increase taxes, which will have a disastrous impact, especially on country areas.

I refer to two areas of significance to my electorate-that is, the sales tax on wine and citrus. Despite firm promises not to impose a new wine tax, the Government first imposed a tax on wine in 1985, and now it has doubled the tax to 20 per cent. It will be recalled that in 1983 the Government imposed an excise on grape spirit used in the fortification of wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a mistake.

—It was a mistake. Under pressure from the Opposition and industry, it withdrew it in May 1984, but that did not stop the Government. Later that year it imposed a sales tax, which it has doubled. The Government was not going to give up in its determination to break the pledge it gave to the people of this country not to impose a tax on wine.
—And break the grape growers, too.

—It will break the grape growers. Certainly, it will break some grape growers. I remember the campaign when we were in government and were urged to put a tax on wine. Treasury and the brewers urged us to put a tax on wine. Nevertheless, over seven years we resisted the temptation to put a sales tax on the wine industry. That is not so with this Government. It is determined to squeeze the last drop of tax out of the industry, even if that means doing substantial damage to the viability of many in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax is introduced at a time when major sections of the industry are in real financial difficulty, particularly in the Riverland in South Australia. According to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, since the 1984 imposition of sales tax, the real price of wine has fallen by about 5 per cent. Growers have had to absorb the tax increase because of the very competitive wine sales market. In 1986-87, returns to wine grape growers with average farm income on family farms are expected to be minus $700. In the area which includes a number of war service settlement blocks along the River Murray in the Riverland, the impact of the extra tax will be, for many, the final straw.

The Government has already acknowledged the depth of the problem by granting funds for vine pull. About 400 growers will share in a total of $5.25m of State and Federal funds spent in the 1985-86 vine pull. However, that will still leave some 300 growers who applied for, but were not granted, funds under that scheme. That was before the latest increase in tax. The number of growers who will now seek vine pull funds, inevitably, will substantially increase.

For a government that pretends to be interested in the small battler, and to have a social conscience, this move to throw a large number of blockers in my area or to the economic scrap-heap is economic and social vandalism. The painful process of structural adjustment was steadily taking place to the advantage of those being assisted out of the industry and to the benefit of those who stayed in it. Already, in the past 10 years or so, the number of hectares under vines has dropped from 71,000 to around 64,000. The trickle of those needing assistance will be turned by this Government's additional tax into a torrent.

The increased tax comes at a time when there are already over 2,000 people in the Riverland area on the unemployment benefit. The Labor Government has been told frequently that now is not the time to tax the wine industry, but it has ignored that advice. Its own inquiry, the McKay Inquiry into the Grape and Wine Industry, gave it that advice. Its Labor State colleagues in Victoria, in a report on the wine industry by the Victorian Parliament, made the following recommendation:
That, given the estimated elastic demand for wine and having concern for the existing level of taxation on the industry, the State Government-
that is, the Victorian Government-
should seek the co-operation of the Commonwealth Government to not increase the overall taxation on wine.

Where is Mr Cain now? We know that many people have raised their voices against an increase in tax on wine. However, what we do not know is what the many Government back benchers who are affected by the measure are doing. What are the honourable members for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and Ballarat (Mr Mildren) saying? The honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) has the wine maker Hardy's in his area. That will be seriously affected by the tax. Where are the honourable members for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) and Calare (Mr Simmons)? Why are they not here standing up for their constituents who will be cast on the economic scrap-heap as a result of the tax? They have left their constituents high and dry. This tax is a disaster. While we have made it clear that we will not block the Government's Budget, I urge the Cabinet to listen to the sweet voice of reason and reverse its decision. If it does not do so, I promise it that it will reap the electoral backlash it deserves.

The other major industry in the Riverland is the citrus industry. That is also being slugged by the Government in this Budget. That industry has been hit with a new sales tax-a 10 per cent sales tax on citrus juices. After a relatively good year last year, the citrus industry has been subject to import competition from frozen orange juice concentrate from Brazil at prices which are so low that they suggest that dumping is taking place. The industry approached the Government for action early in the year. In May this year, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said that action would be taken and that there would be an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry. Where is the inquiry? Months went past and nothing happened. Four months later, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) eventually announced, after the Budget, that there would be an IAC inquiry. In the meantime, Brazilian imports have steadily eroded domestic prices.

Citrus producers currently hold stocks of 195,000 tonnes, which is equal to 45 per cent of the year's consumption of about 472,000 tonnes. The Government has picked now to impose a tax on the industry. This will be the first time that a tax has been imposed on a food such as orange juice. Tax is not imposed on the bacon and eggs which a person has for breakfast. It is not imposed on the milk one puts on one's cereals or on the cereals. But if one dares to have an orange juice one will pay the tax. For the first time, this Government has extended sales tax to the food industry. Where is the equity in that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mineral water.

—Honourable members opposite joke. They will not be here after the next election, as a result of this and a number of the other aggressive taxation actions that the Government has taken. It is the highest taxing government this country has ever seen. This blow to the citrus industry comes at a time when citrus growers are building a valuable fresh fruit export market. But there will always be a percentage of the crop that is unsuitable for fresh sales, so the juice market is a vital part of the financial viability of the citrus growers. The industry claims that the price increase as a result of the tax will force consumers out of the 100 per cent juice category to the cheaper fruit beverages with lower fruit content, and thus reduce the demand for processed citrus.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry claims that the Government's likely revenue from the measure this year is $15.7m and that the disastrous social consequences will cost the community $196m. Where is the economic sense in that? There will be more unemployment benefit payments and the social consequences of these two sales tax measures taken together will be disastrous in areas such as the Riverland.

These taxes are not fair or equitable. They are economic insanity. They are a further blow to the rural sector of this country. This Government seems to be intent on doing everything it can to ride the rural sector to its knees, and these two measures in particular in this sales tax legislation are a disaster. I urge the Government to review the wine tax and the tax on citrus products in the interests of all those involved in those two industries.

It strikes me that it governs with whatever it feels is expedient at the time. That sort of approach is currently crippling two of South Australia's major industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After a Budget has been brought down, of course, it is usual for the Parliament to consider sales tax Bills because during the year it becomes obvious to the Government, the Opposition, the community and the Australian Taxation Office that a number of anomalies have developed in the application of the sales tax provisions. I think it is obvious that, if we were to go among members of the Parliament on both sides of the House, we would find different attitudes, different responses, to some of these provisions. I would be less than honest if I were to say, for example, that I was happy with all of them. The simple fact is that I am not. Nor would any one member of this Parliament be able honestly to say that every aspect of these three sales tax Bills-the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax Acts Amendment Bill-is one that he or she would personally support.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand, too, the advantage which is taken by members of the Opposition in order to pursue some of these questions and to make it appear that if they were in government the situation would be otherwise. I would like to refer in particular to some of these provisions. TALK.START.PARA: —A great car.
—A great car. Alexander Downer probably has one. If he has, it cost him $220,000.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, in keeping with your earlier rulings, I am compelled to ask you to ask the honourable member to refer to the honourable member for Mayo by his correct title.
—The point of order is quite correct. I am sure that the honourable member for Charlton will refer to him by his proper title.

—The honourable member for Mayo probably has a Silver Spirit in the dolls' house. Before the increase, it would have cost him $220,000. If he buys one now, after the increase, it will cost him $235,000. My constituents, for that amount of money, would probably buy--

—Most of my constituents, who buy secondhand cars, could buy 100 secondhand motor cars for that money. TALK.START.PARA: —The Browns.

—I claim no credit for the Browns' wines, but someone in my clan, as the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has said, has made a great contribution to the development of quality wines in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —If there were a tax to be levied on intoxicating speeches, I think that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) would be up for a massive tax payment to the Taxation Office. He has told us of everyone who has won a medal for wines in his district and I congratulate everyone to whom he referred. I hope that everyone can continue to produce despite the impost that is to be placed on them by the Government. Notwithstanding the supposed reform of the Australian tax system, which is in effect a mish-mash of consensus politics, our tax regime is now but a relic of its former self. Sales tax once had a simple rate and a broad base but now it has multiple rates and fewer commodities in its taxable base. I will concede that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has broadened the tax base, particularly since September 1985. However, the apparently indiscriminate use of broadening the base appears to be motivated more by a requirement for revenue than by the following of a preconceived plan.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that everyone accepts that taxes are necessary to finance government expenditure. There is no argument there. Some of these `goods' could be provided by the market, such as health and education but others could not, such as the police, a service which benefits everybody except, perhaps, the criminal element. Another example is defence. It is impossible for such services to be priced in the market-place. It is recognised that governments have an onerous task in ensuring that taxes are levied and that subsequent expenditures satisfy the basic requirements of equity, efficiency and simplicity.

Another important consideration is that the cost effectiveness of each tax is related closely to the revenue which it raises. That is because the cost incurred in the administration of a tax is largely independent of the tax rates that are applied. There is no doubt that the cost of collection falls more heavily on the private sector than the public sector as it is there that sales are recorded and sales tax is determined. It is within the private sector that forms are processed and it is those within the private sector who ensure that cheques are delivered within the required 21 days, unless they want to incur a penalty.

No understanding is shown for the longer periods of credit that are required during depressed economic circumstances. This is something that should be taken up in respect of the time that is given to companies to reimburse sales tax moneys from their manufacture.

A previous speaker, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), when referring to the imposition of sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juice, said this was the first time that a tax had been placed on food. But it is not; it is the second time. Last year a tax was placed on ice cream, which is considered to be a food according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics in its consumer price index calculations. As a result of a survey by a Queensland Institute of Technology nutritionist ice cream was considered as vital for correcting a calcium deficiency in Australian school children. Therefore this is not the first time we have had a tax on food, but the second time, so there has been a progressive move to placing a tax on food.

The imposition of sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juice will mean that our local milk and fruit juice vendors will be regarded as wholesale merchants for a substantial part of their day's trading and as retailers for the remainder. These people buy from a distributor, be it a factory or whatever, and in some cases then sell direct to the public as retailers. In this case their supplier is effectively the wholesale merchant and adds the necessary sales tax to the price of the product on the invoice. In those cases where the milk or fruit juice vendors will be selling to shops such procedure as mentioned before does not apply. What happens is that the vendors now become wholesale merchants and add the sales tax figure to the invoice and effectively become gatherers of tax. The procedure is further complicated where the vendors travel some distance to outlying areas and that introduces an element of freight into the wholesale cost of the product. Of course freight is taxable so it must be added to the wholesale price before the sales tax component is calculated. In addressing this problem of sales tax on freight, I notice that the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), speaking as a member of the Hawke Government's rural policy committee, is mentioned in an article in the Sunday Sun of 29 September 1985. He said that freight was an enormous component in rural living costs. He mentioned that it was taxable and that he was seeking from the Treasurer some means of balancing this sort of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who mentioned that?

—The honourable member for Capricornia, who is another one who is a lion in his electorate and a lamb when he gets down here. As yet there have been no offsets to a removal of the impost of sales tax on freight for rural Australians, so I take it he has not pursued the matter too strongly or he may be finding it a little difficult. I think most of us would recognise that the sales tax component on freight is a difficult question to be resolved. I believe it is one on which we should take a bipartisan approach in this House to see whether we can find out how it can be resolved. The Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Hurford, on 16 October stated in Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are all interested in this issue. We would love to be able to do something about it. However, it is a very complex issue. Years ago it was considered by a Senate select committee and to date no one has been able to devise a legislative solution to this problem.

He is silent on it now, and silence is certainly not a significant characteristic of the Prime Minister, because he is ready to speak on all things at all times. But he has remained-

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget has been promoted as being a low deficit Budget. It is nothing but a sham. There has been little in the way of real cuts but a facade of deferments and postponements and windfall profits for the Reserve Bank of Australia. Outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product are still higher than ever before. So it is still a big spending government which is taxing the children of this country to finance its profligate spending. All it is doing is taking the money out of children's piggy banks by taxing flavoured milk and fruit juice.

I will wind up by saying that this Government has been a very high taxing government. There is no doubt about it; the records have shown that. No matter how much it tries to place all the problems, the ills and the woes of this nation on a previous government, it is just not wearing with the people in the general community. They will not buy that because it has been going on for too long. This Government has been in office long enough to correct any perceived ills that it may want to say are there. This Government is going to go on imposing higher and higher taxes because the only way it can finance programs that it has instituted will be to raise more taxes. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in expressing my great concern about the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill and cognate Bills that have been brought before the House, and in particular I join with the honourable members for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and Barker (Mr Porter) in condemning in the strongest of terms the doubling of the wine tax, which is part and parcel of this package of Bills, which compensates for the Government's failure to cut back on public expenditure in the recent Budget. The wine tax affects my electorate in a very real way, particularly the areas of the Southern Vales and Langhorne Creek. The Southern Vales are particularly relevant in this debate because at the town of McLaren Vale in 1983 the now Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) accompanied by the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) addressed a public meeting. At that meeting they promised that an Australian Labor Party Government would not introduce a wine tax. That promise was as hollow as so many of the other promises we have heard from this so-called Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that the Government has not only broken its promise but imposed yet another tax, another impost on the enterprising part of Australia. After all, wine making and grape growing is something that Australians actually do well and it is an industry that has enormous potential for the future and in particular potential in export markets. Yet the Government is milking this industry in order to finance the squandermania of socialism, which is what Labor is always about. This wine tax, this doubling of the wine tax I should say because we already have a wine tax, comes at a critical time for the industry. Indeed it could not have come at a worse time as officers from the Department of Primary Industry will be only too aware. This is a time when the industry is suffering from over production and there is a need to reduce those problems of surpluses. But those problems should not be exacerbated by a doubling of the wine tax. Rationalisation will come about by its own means. Secondly-this is related to the first point-wine sales in the last financial year increased by just 1.5 per cent, which is the lowest level of increase since 1970-71. In other words, in terms of sales the industry is running into a great deal of difficulty already without the added imposition of a doubling of the wine tax. There was an increase in sales in the industry only because of the introduction of what are called coolers, which found a very ready market in Australia.

The causes of the slump in wine sales are numerous but it is important to enumerate just a couple of them. First of all, the effects of a 10 per cent wine tax are now flowing through into the market-place. It is interesting to observe that in the year the wine tax was introduced, in 1984, growth in sales was 5.6 per cent. Now that the 10 per cent tax is having an effect on the industry, growth has already fallen to 1.5 per cent. The industry's growth has also been inhibited by high levels of imports from the European Economic Community-although it is true that the devaluation is helping to cope with those problems now-it has been inhibited by the highest interest rates Australia has known, and it has been inhibited by the introduction of the entertainment tax. With a doubling of the wine tax, prospects for the next financial year are a fall in sales of 3.4 per cent. The industry is heading into a recession and something like $20m worth of sales are expected to be lost next year.

The third reason why this is a critical time for the industry is that prices are depressed, and that obviously affects not just the wineries but the grape growers. In the 1985-86 financial year prices increased by 2.4 per cent compared with a increase in the consumer price index of 8.2 per cent. Clearly, growers are being crushed and so are the wineries.

Fourthly, the industry is being hit by an almost exponential increase in production costs. The costs of processing aids and equipment have increased in the last year by 50 per cent; and whilst the devaluation obviously will help export penetration, it is important to remember that the costs for wine producers associated with imports are very significant and that devaluation, in particular, has forced up the costs of things such as wine presses and corks, which cannot be produced in Australia.

All this has led to a very severe decline in the profitability of the industry. The return on capital in the industry is now less than 5 per cent, and as the honourable member for Barker and the honourable member for Wakefield pointed out, growers' incomes in 1986-87 are expected to decline by some 30 per cent. One-third of grape growers in the industry are now in very real difficulties. In South Australia alone 700 growers are applying for the vine pull scheme. More land under vines in South Australia is being torn up than in all the Hunter Valley.

Let me refer to the taxation arrangements for the industry. It is important to note in the first place that the 10 per cent tax was largely absorbed initially by the wineries. However, that meant that the wineries had less money to pass on to the growers. So the people who suffered initially were the growers, and that, of course, is why the vine pull scheme has been not only so necessary but also so popular in the industry. This new doubling of the wine tax has been opposed by everybody in the industry. That goes without saying. It was also opposed by the McKay Inquiry into the Grape and Wine Industries, set up by the Minister for Primary Industry to investigate the state of the wine industry. I understand that it has been opposed very strongly by officers of the Department of Primary Industry. That is not surprising when one looks at the tax situation in the wine industry. The total tax burden on an industry with a turnover this year of $624m will be $241m. The 20 per cent wine tax will take $124m, State licensing fees will take another $82m and the brandy excise yet another $35m. When all of the industry's costs have been paid on top of the taxes, it will end up with profits of around $30m.

Let us look at the tax to profit ratio. For every $1 that that industry has earned in profits, it has paid out $8 in tax. So it pays $8 tax for every $1 profit. When one compares that ratio with that of the breweries, and of the manufacturers of spirits-who are mainly foreign-one sees that the wine industry is not a privileged industry; it is an industry which is very much on its knees. Doubling the wine tax is simply savaging an industry when it is at its weakest. The Australian Labor Party always pretends-we know it is a pretence-that it is a party of compassion. There has been no evidence of it in the last three years. It pretends that it is a party of compassion, and yet it will kick an industry when it is down. I think that is pretty unattractive.

The result of this measure will be that the Government will be forced to pay enormous compensation to growers and wineries which will be made to fail because of Labor's taxation policies. The Government says that it has increased its contributions to the vine pull scheme by some $3m. Clearly, that amount will be totally inadequate. More money will have to be provided for the vine pull scheme; more money will have to be provided to the industry through the rural adjustment scheme; and, of course, social security payments will pick up where growers are forced out of the industry altogether and can find nothing else to do. It is estimated by a lot of people in the industry that the Commonwealth will be forced to pay out an extra $20m to the industry as a result of this enormous imposition of a doubling of the wine tax.

I think it is also important to mention that the Government should do some constructive things to try to help the industry. It could start by producing a wine policy, because one of the things the wine industry lacks is stability. Under the Fraser Government it had seven years of stability, but under this Government twice it has had unexpected tax impositions placed on it. If there is one message one gets from growers and the wineries it is: `Please tell us what you are doing. Give us some stability so we can plan for the future. We don't want a lot of bureaucrats and a lot of politicians coming up with their clever ideas which bear no relationship to the problems on the ground. Most of those people have never spoken to anybody on the ground and have no compassionate understanding of the industry or even an economic understanding of the prospects this industry really has'. Talking of prospects, it is about time this Government did something to try to promote exports for this country in all the sorts of ways the Opposition has been describing. It is about time the Government looked at creative ways of helping the wine industry's exports.

Recently I was at the Bristol wine fair in the west of England-one of the best of all the European wine fairs-and the Australian contribution to that wine fair could only be described as utterly pathetic. The Australian Government, through the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, is not providing the resources to help wine exports. If only the Government would promote our products on the world market-they are as good as one will find anywhere in the world-perhaps the industry will have some future.

Finally, let me point out that the Government first introduced a 10 per cent tax, then it doubled it to 20 per cent, and yet it has never produced a single economic study of the industry. It has made no effort to find out what the consequences of the fringe benefits tax would be for the car industry, and now it knows that it has suffered $1 billion-worth of lost sales. It has done nothing of that sort for the wine industry either-no economic study, no policies for the future; just a lot of bureaucratic claptrap and impositions which are so much part of the socialist philosophy.

In conclusion, this is a government which is not interested in productivity. It is hitting the creative and productive parts of the Australian economy with ever-increasing taxes and redistributing those funds to all its friends in the trade union movement, peace groups and fellow travellers with the Labor Party. It is about time the Labor Party and the Government as a whole woke up, examined the problems of our industries in a constructive way and did something to help our country get ahead. Doubling the wine tax is destructive and unnecessary.

I do not want members of the Opposition coming into this House and pontificating about what the Government should or could have done at the Taxation Summit. Let the people of Australia understand that we have brought in a tax reform package, the greatest tax reform legislation that this country has seen in many years, without one scintilla of assistance from the Opposition.

I was staggered to hear the shadow Treasurer arguing against the tax that has been imposed on luxury motor vehicles. The honourable member for Mayo suggested that the Australian Labor Party is a party of compassion. I agree with him on that point, but I am staggered that the coalition parties still seek to maintain their traditional ground as the parties of privilege and oppose this measure which imposes an increase from 20 per cent sales tax to 30 per sales tax on high priced luxury motor cars. I am staggered that the Opposition would not defend the desire of the ordinary people of Australia to own a Commodore, a Falcon or any other Australian made cars, but would wish to protect the importation of Rolls-Royces, Bentleys, Mercedes and Volvos. Once again we find the coalition parties complaining bitterly about the imposition of this luxury tax. TALK.START.PARA: —He opposed them.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the compromising of exports. I quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) in which he quotes the Treasurer (Mr Keating):

TALK.START.PARA: —Stabbed them in the back.

SPEECH.PARA: It is merely a matter once again of the Government taking very bad advice and one can almost see the political background to it-let us hit all of those industries that do not have big employment and that do not have the basis that city-based industries have, and let us bash the country once again. One starts at a level of the sort that has been introduced in this legislation and it escalates beyond reason as time goes on. Earlier this afternoon the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) referred to this aspect. It will be a burden beyond all burdens for small business. I believe that this tax is in tandem with the fringe benefits tax. This country has enjoyed some sanity in the way taxes have been collected in the past. SPEECH.PARA: It is important to realise that although we are told that within the context of such taxes we are collecting an additional amount of tax in the name of equity and fairness and to stop rorts, it is nothing of the kind. TALK.START.PARA: —The artful dodger has another tax rort.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax represents an attack not only on consumers but also on small business people. TALK.START.PARA: —The performance of honourable members opposite-such as the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), all of whom are from South Australia-has been amazing. Journalists who drink, savour and write about wine probably know wine as well as the judges. That winery received top award at that show. I mention Yarra Burn, owned by the Fyffes; Mount Mary of John Middleton, which has won acclaim overseas, increasing its export sales to California; Fergussons; and Yeringberg to mention a few. They are top wineries. Those wineries will benefit from the devaluation of the Australian dollar. The wineries are strongly associated with tourism. The Yarra Valley, the Barossa Valley, the Hunter Valley, and elsewhere, will receive more and more high-income visitors from Japan and the United States of America with money to spend who will savour our top wines. When they return to their countries, thanks to the devaluation of the Australian dollar and the promotion of the trade commissioners overseas, there will be a greatly expanding market for exports of top quality table wines. The Yarra Valley wineries will be at the top.

I remind honourable members opposite that I have more confidence in the wine industry than they have. I do not believe that it should have excessive protection. I believe, as do the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and this Government, that the 10 per cent increase in sales tax puts it on a more equitable footing with competitive commodities such as beer, and so on. Those commodities do not need protection. I have confidence, as do the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Government, that the wine industry will be able to expand, given the Budget that we have prepared. People argue, for instance, that the wine industry has enjoyed an increase in sales. The honourable member for Mayo said that there was an increase last year of 1 to 2 per cent. Perhaps it has plateaued-Australia is one of the largest consumers of wine, in terms of litres per head of population, and one cannot expect sales to grow astronomically all the time. When the 10 per cent sales tax was introduced, the wine industry largely absorbed the extra cost, and it was very hard to judge the true impact on the response of buyers to the rise in sales tax. But we have a different position with this increase of another 10 per cent. The major buyers of top table wines-of premium wine-are enjoying big tax cuts. Towards the end of this year, they will have more money in their pockets. They will be able to enjoy more wine and buy more wine despite the increase in the sales tax.

That is my point. The people opposite, who pretend to represent the wine industry, have never really talked to them and have never seen their operations in the context of the Budget as a whole. They are trying to curry favour by pretending that they will fight the sales tax, but in reality they are not doing that, because they believe in high consumption taxes. At the same time, they are not being truthful enough to realise that consumers, with more money in their pockets, and devaluation, which means more tourists with more money in their pockets, will lead to greater promotion of wine and more sales in the wine industry.

Let me give honourable members one concrete example of how this Government has urged our trade commissioners overseas to encourage people to consume Australian wine. Let us turn to London, which is only one capital city, where, in the last 12 months, under Austrade-the campaign for Australian exports-30,000 dozen bottles of top Australian table wine have been sold. Yet in the five years before these campaigns by the Government, only 5,000 dozen bottles of wine were sold.

What is it that makes the wine industry tick? It is not protection; it is not special or favourable treatment, as those opposite want-it is having enough confidence in the industry to know that it will stand on its own two feet, and promoting it. People buy wine because they can afford it, and with the tax cuts they can buy more. With promotion, with Austrade and with the devaluation of the dollar, our wineries are poised to exploit the opportunity. Instead of French and Californian wine coming here and swamping the market, people will turn to the local product, and why should they not? In every place in Australia that produces wine we can find a top product.

It is also said of this Government that it is encouraging beer as the workers' drink as against wine. I take it, therefore, that the people opposite think that only high income earners-only the elite of society-drink wine. Nothing could be further from the truth. The fact is that wine is marketed and presented in various forms, qualities and volumes. Due to the promotion of the wine industry, the worker now drinks vast quantities of cask wine and, in addition, is introducing himself to bottled wine. The fact is that the worker, the middle income earner and the high income earner are all consumers of wine, so let us hear no more from the Opposition that this Government has turned its back on the wine industry or wants to bash it around the head. Through devaluation, overseas promotion and tax cuts, the wine industry will enjoy the future that it has wanted for years.

Let me give one more example of how this Government, through its buy Australia campaign and through devaluation, has been able to assist the wine industry. As a member of the rural task force who talks to representatives of the wine industry, I was told that the little caps that go on the top of wine bottles had doubled in price due to cost increases overseas and devaluation. Due to support and promotion by the Australian Government, for the first time an Australian manufacturer is ready to produce the same seals for the bottles at half the price. That is one more example of how this Government sees the wine industry not in terms of tax revenue but in terms of promotion.

We know that with the tax reforms that have been introduced, the wine industry will enjoy increased sales, increased income and increased employment. It is true that the McKay Inquiry into the Grape and Wine Industry said that there should be a period of adjustment and review before any further increase in sales tax. But because the sales tax was largely absorbed by the wineries, it was difficult to calculate thoroughly the price elasticity of demand for wine given that sales tax increase. However, there had been a further increase in the consumption of wine, so, with due review, we have felt it appropriate within the Budget context not to continue this special treatment to the wine industry. I have found it increasingly difficult, as I have said to winery after winery, to defend this privileged treatment vis-a-vis the 10 per cent advantage in sales tax over similar commodities. I have said to them, and they accept it, that we see it in the context of the Budget, with its advantages for consumers and advantages for producers.

Far from what the Opposition has said, this Government sees the wine industry in the whole context of taxation reform and industry generally. We are not politicking, as the Opposition would have it, on the 10 per cent sales tax. I and the Government believe that we have a solid, sound wine industry, and we are confident that it will prosper.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member before me, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) indicated, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) is about the removal of import restrictions on gold and, to put it in its proper context, it is part of the move that this Government has made towards reducing those areas of regulation in the economy where we believe that regulation should sensibly be removed. I think it is important to reflect-for the benefit of the honourable member for Deakin-that when the Opposition parties were in power, they were reluctant to reduce this sort of regulation. The Australian community has less than fond memories of that experience. The Opposition did not take up the substantial issues of reducing regulation, and we well know it. This piece of legislation is really about reducing that regulation, so we have to get it in place.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the internationalisation of the Australian economy, this Government has moved, where possible, to reduce restraints upon trade. It is interesting to reflect upon the work of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) at the moment in Uruguay. In particular, the flotation of the Australian dollar was one of the ways in which this Government brought a more responsive and flexible Australian economy into the world scene. The previous Government failed to address itself to that matter; it dodged the issue and left us with a massively overvalued exchange rate. This piece of legislation fits within the framework of what we would regard as suitable deregulation of the Australian economy, and I think we really have to test that. The performance of this Government with respect to regulation has been to deregulate in areas which the Opposition, when in government, was unwilling to act. We could spend a moment or two reflecting upon why that may be the case, but I do not think it is appropriate in this debate. However, I think it is appropriate to point out that when the opportunity was there-there was substantial opportunity-the Liberal and National parties did not proceed towards such a pattern of deregulation.

From the point of view of Western Australia, my home State, removing this import restriction is very important, because in Western Australia we are moving towards a more effective gold mining industry. I will say something more about that in a moment. Our move towards a more effective gold mining industry has been taken up particularly by the State Government. I note for the record that the State Government has been very effective in recent times in trying to market Australian gold internationally. That climate is very important, and we should be seen to be fostering it. Clearly, the opportunity for this country to become a place in which gold reserves can be based is a very important move.

The honourable member for Deakin talked about political stability. He raised a number of issues, but I do not think that on an international view-if we were to compare Australia with a number of other countries-Australia would be seen as politically unstable. Clearly, that is not the case. Australia has been politically stable. If we talk about instability, I suppose we can refer only to 1975 as being a period of contrived instability. Again, this debate is not the appropriate place to talk about that, but it is important to say that on a world scene, the Australian economy and the Australian Government are seen as having great stability and performance. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed to the recent assessment by Moody's Investor Services Inc. of the capacity of the Australian Government to manage international and domestic issues. What we are saying with respect to this legislation is that we believe that as part of the internationalisation of the Australian economy, not only are we allowing the entry of foreign banks into Australia-that is clearly long overdue-but we are also allowing the Australian dollar to float. The third aspect is that we are saying that if people overseas wish to use the Australian economy as a place in which they can base gold reserves, we would provide a suitable base for those reserves.

Clearly, we have a sophisticated infrastructure. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) would say that the future lies in our becoming very sophisticated in terms of our ideas, the level of sophistication of technology we must have and the people who go with that technology. This is part of the move towards saying: `We have a lot to offer our immediate region'. For example, our immediate region can benefit from the skill level in the Australian work force, the high level of formal education offered, the skills and reliability of communications systems, the effective banking system we have, and the historical experience of having had democratic governments for a long time. All of these factors, when put into context, suggest that we are saying to the world community: `In terms of your judgment and of our performance, we are prepared to offer the Australian economy if you wish to base gold reserves here or undertake other sorts of investment activities. We believe that we can stand up and be counted'. That is what this legislation is really about. I think my colleague indicated his support for that measure. It is a view we are getting across to the Australian community, and it is long overdue. For a long time we have said: `We have a very narrowly defined economy and we have very narrow expectations for ourselves'. We are saying that that does not have to be the case. We can have an economy that has high levels of expectations and high levels of performance, and we can redefine our capabilities.

We on this side of the House are very clear. We believe that we have the work force, that we have the infrastructure and that we have the performance. We can certainly provide the leadership at the level of government to deliver in terms of industries-and this is one of those. As the honourable member for Deakin has indicated, currently the matter of the gold tax is of some concern. Western Australia is concerned about the level of production, the performance of marginal mines and whether the gold tax will result in a net gain to revenue. Those are the sorts of issues about which we are concerned. However, I can say with some confidence that those are the sorts of issues that Cabinet is addressing, and clearly, they are issues we would regard as being of considerable importance in terms of the operation of a gold mining industry if there were to be a gold tax.

I think there is a need to put an interpretation upon this legislation. This legislation is about saying that we desire the removal of impediments to the movement of gold bullion into this country. The removal of those impediments is very important, because we believe that we can offer an economy which is sophisticated, politically stable and capable of performing. I know that honourable members opposite have made some remarks that go towards that, but clearly, if one looks at the macro picture, at the level of employment, at the level of production and at the general overall question of economic growth and the direction of the economy, it stands to reason that people overseas would say: `Yes, we do have faith in the Australian economy'. We on this side are in no doubt about that.

It gives many honourable members on this side of the House a lot of pleasure to be able to say at the moment that what we are endorsing to the Australian community is: `Get out there and support the Australian economy; get out there and buy Australian; get out there and get behind what we regard as being a good, effective Australian economy that can deliver goods and services of high quality to its own market and international markets'. When we ask: `Will people overseas be prepared, for example, to risk gold bullion in the Australian community?', we have no doubt about the answer. We see ourselves as having a regional role. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) is charting a whole new agenda as far as our regional role is concerned, and it is an admirable move.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Minister for Trade.

—The Minister for Trade is setting standards, as my colleague mentions, in terms of what we regard as the rational way to conduct trade. SPEECH.PARA: We are pleased that this legislation is one of the many moves that this Government has undertaken towards the developing sophistication of the Australian economy. We are confident that the leadership is there to be shown.

Originally it had been expected that the report would have been dealt with and the decision announced a good deal earlier, but there was a request both from the Gold Policy Committee and the Western Australian Government to extend the date by two months. It meant that the reporting date was delayed until 29 August 1986. I think one would have to say that three weeks or so is not an undue delay given the precedents set by the Fraser Government and other governments in dealing with reports on sensitive matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has already indicated that if any legislative measure were to be introduced after the report was considered such measures would have effect from 1 July 1986. I think people know where they stand. Things are coming to a pretty pass when the Opposition starts raising political objections to the legislation proposed by the Government, an offence I thought compounded by the honourable member for Deakin by his ranging so widely. I am glad to see that my colleague from Western Australia, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), pushed the State interest just a bit and hardly raised politics at all. I thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate.

(1) the failure of the Budget to tackle Australia's fundamental economic problems, namely:
