SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget is a complete failure. It does not face up to the economic disaster confronting Australia; it provides no solutions to that impending disaster and, if anything, it will only make the economy worse than it is now. It has been almost universally rejected and condemned both within Australia and overseas. The final and most humiliating rejection came on 10 September, Australia's day of shame as I described it this morning, when Moody's Investor Services Inc. denied us, for the first time, our AAA rating and Australia was held up to international ridicule.

SPEECH.PARA: What are we faced with in the Australian economy? We have an inflation rate that is twice the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and many times the inflation rate of the countries we trade with, we have interest rates that have gone through the roof, we are now trading at a loss of $14 billion a year, we have enormous overseas debts that put us up with the big league of debtor nations, we have negative economic growth, we have investment that is actually set to fall this year, we have now had two consecutive quarterly declines in production in our manufacturing industries, and, to cap it all off, we now have rising unemployment that is already higher than it was during virtually the whole of the seven years of the Fraser Government. Surely that is enough, without any more, to demonstrate to anyone that the Australian economy is in decline and that we face a disastrous situation. Surely that is enough to demonstrate to anyone that we needed urgent action to be taken in the Budget-urgent action to reduce government spending to get our inflation rate and interest rates down, urgent action to stimulate investment, and urgent action to get the taxation burden off the backs of business people and to restore incentive and encourage people to have a go. But instead of that urgent action, we have been given a Budget that shows nothing more than that the Government is suffering from sclerosis. All that we got was the same old lack of leadership, the same big spending, the same tax burden sapping the incentive of the productive sector and the same old refusal to face up to the rigidities and the stitched-up inflexibilities of so much of our economy.

The biggest single failure of the Budget, and the failure that I want to concentrate on, is its utterly inadequate response on wages policy. The strategy of the Budget, so far as there is any strategy to be perceived in it at all, is apparently a strategy, so it is said, based on the twin approach of tightening fiscal and wages policies. The Government has clearly failed on the first of these because it has utterly failed to bring down a sufficiently tight fiscal result. It has failed to tackle any of the big items of expenditure and many of the so-called cuts in expenditure are nothing more than delays and postponements in expenditure. It has not cut expenditure; it has simply postponed it.

Government spending this year will total 29.4 per cent of gross domestic product, the fourth largest percentage in our history-the three largest are the other three Hawke-Keating Budgets. And if we needed any evidence of this at all, we now know it to be true because the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) have both admitted as much by saying that we need a mini-Budget to implement further cuts in expenditure. So much for the fiscal side. The Government has also failed on the other leg of its apparent approach because it has failed to deliver the promised tighter wages policy. Not only has it failed to deliver a tighter wages policy, but it also has failed to do a single thing to use our wages structure and our industrial relations structure to encourage employers and employees to exert themselves and to increase productivity.

Before the Budget, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told us that when we got the Budget we would see that it contained, as he called it, an unequivocal statement on wages. We certainly got that. We got an unequivocal statement that in the face of a shrinking economy, with falling investment and rising prices, the Government would push for a 2 per cent wage increase. It dresses it up, of course, by saying that it will argue for the 2 per cent discounting of a 4 per cent claim in the next national wage case. But, stripped of this smokescreen, the Government will argue for a two per cent wage increase to be piled on top of a stalled economy, on top of high inflation and on top of rising unemployment. As if that is not enough, the Government also wants to pile on top of our wage structure a further wage increase of 4 to 5 per cent next April, with no undertaking that it will argue for any discounting at all.

This is an utterly irresponsible position for the Government to take at a time when the economy is clearly starting to grind to a halt. To make it worse, the Government peddles the absurd claim that this policy of higher wages would see wage outcomes broadly in line with those of our major trading partners. That is the basis on which we are said to be going to trade out of our economic difficulties. This is utterly false and has no foundation whatsoever. I say that because the Budget Papers tell us that nominal wage increases for the next year will be over 6 per cent. The average for our OECD trading partners will be 4 1/2 per cent, in the United States of America wages will increase by less than 2 1/2 per cent, and in Japan they will increase by less than 2 1/2 per cent. They are countries whose terms of trade, like those of most of our trading partners, will improve this year when Australia's terms of trade will continue to decline even further.

So when we are faced with rising inflation, rising unemployment, rising costs and shrinking trade, what is the Government's response? Its response is to increase wages by 2 per cent now and to increase them by more than our trading partners will increase theirs. If the Government were not blinded by its complete adulation of the trade union movement, it would see what it is plain for everyone else to see-that this is a formula for absolute disaster. To pile more wage costs on to a struggling and shrinking economy is exactly that-a formula for disaster.

It should be plain to anyone that the 2 per cent discount is certainly not enough when Australia is faced with the economic factors with which it is faced. It is nothing more than a political figure forced on to the Government by the strait-jacket of the prices and incomes accord which has shackled the Government and which now shackles the economy of this country. There is only one responsible course open to the Government-to support full discounting for both the direct and the indirect effects that the depreciation of our dollar has had on the consumer price index and to then argue for that in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with all of the authority and all of the conviction that a central government can carry. Not only is this common sense but also the Treasury has told the Government that it is common sense. I say that because in the Budget Papers we are told:

If we are to hold the competitive gains of the past 18 months, labour cost increases in Australia will need to be kept broadly in line with those of our major trading partners. That is critical to fostering the necessary restructuring of the economy, and related to that, more buoyant levels of business investment.
The Budget Papers go on to say:
If adequate profitability is to be achieved, additional restraint needs to be placed on labour costs.

Yet in the face of common sense and in the face of what the Government has been told by the Treasury it should do, the Government has taken the politically expedient course of promoting a wage increase that will put our wage costs well above those of other trading nations, and that way spells disaster. If wages are to play their part in economic recovery, we have to do more than have complete and full wage discounting. Indeed, as we in the Opposition put it, we have to change our whole industrial relations and wage fixing structure. If we do not do that, we will continue to have wage increases piled on to the cost structure of all of our industries, even though they clearly cannot afford to pay.

I say that because that is the essence of our present centralised system. If a case for a wage increase is made out, because of the very fact that the system is universal and is compulsory, that wage increase is applied to all industries and to all employers, big and small, whether they can afford to pay or not and, indeed, even if they have to go out of business as a result of decisions handed down by the Arbitration Commission. That is an accurate description of our present system, but when one describes it like that one must come to the conclusion that it is an utterly absurd system to determine wages. But there is no need for anyone to take my word for it. One can look at the most recent condemnation by overseas observers of this ridiculous system. I have said this before today, and it deserves to be said again, that when Moody's Investor Services Inc. took away our AAA rating, it commented on one of the reasons that justified its action. As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) tried to do today, it is not enough to wipe off this reason by saying that really it was not very important, as this is one of the reasons given by this international agency for reducing our AAA rating. Moody's said:
Industrial and labour market rigidities are further expected to hamper the country's on-going efforts to shift economic resources into areas of high foreign exchange earning capacity.

There is no doubt that Moody's, like all objective observers and, indeed, as common sense would tell us, has come to the conclusion that if one has a rigid system that is compulsory and universal and which is prohibited and prevented from looking at the wages that are needed and the conditions of employment that are needed in individual industries and individual enterprises, one will continue to have resources going into unproductive and uneconomic areas. If the system continues to have that effect, which it will if the system is not reformed, the same thumbs down international judgment will be passed upon the Australian economy as we have seen passed over the last few months.

It is for this very reason that the Opposition has argued-the debate has clearly moved in our direction on this issue, even to the extent that the Prime Minister seems to be picking up parts of it-that we must let individual employers and their employees agree on wages and conditions of employment that are justified by the real world conditions that exist in the individual enterprises in which they work. Until we do this and until we reform our industrial relations system in this way and have it take more account of economic reality than it presently does, we will continue to have resources flowing into unproductive areas, as highlighted by Moody's only a couple of weeks ago. What we in the Opposition say we need in this country if we are going to keep the present industrial relations system, is first of all a system of full discounting because of the devaluation of the Australian currency. That is what we must have if we are going to retain the present system. There must be full discounting because of devaluation, otherwise the system will wreak its own vengeance. What we need far more than that is a new system that will bring flexibility into our wage fixing process and not the phoney flexibility that the Government and the ACTU have dredged up because the whole public debate is now moving swiftly away from them. We need a real flexibility that enables employers and employees to work together for their mutual prosperity by agreeing on wages that the enterprise can pay, wages that the employees know the enterprise can afford, wages that will help the enterprise survive and expand, conditions of employment that will encourage a more productive and happier work force and, above will, work practices that will get costs down and productivity up. What a lame, half-hearted response the Government has given to the need to reform the antiquated work practices that bedevil so much of Australian industry. It is going to have yet another talkfest.

We have to acknowledge that at long last the Prime Minister has seen the need to reform our work practices. But it is a death bed conversion seized on by the Prime Minister before the debate leaves the Government well behind. It is a death bed conversion by a man, after all, who has spent virtually all of his working life piling excessive wages and extravagant conditions on to struggling industries. There is only one way to reform work practices in Australia and that is by changing the law so that we can get employers and employees at the individual work place together so that they can agree amongst themselves to reform the way that work is done, free of the dead hand of the trade unions, and so that they can work together for their mutual prosperity and their mutual success. That is what the present system prevents and deters them from doing. That is why the present system is in such desperate need of reform.

But the Budget, like the Government's whole economic strategy, is silent on reform. Not only is it silent on reform but also it has set its face against the reforms that we so desperately need. The Government has locked this country into high inflation, low investment, big debts and now, it seems, almost guaranteed high unemployment. Its deliberate policy to slow down the economy, its over-reliance on monetary policy and its utterly inadequate wages and fiscal policies will force more people on to the dole queues as the rest of this financial year unfolds. We are already seeing this because unemployment has now gone from 7.6 per cent to 8.3 per cent in only two months. All of the economic indicators show that jobs, like the economy as a whole, are shrinking. As if that were not enough, on top of this the Government has promoted policies that will force interest rates up, discourage investment and stifle incentive by imposing new and higher taxes on business, on wage earners and on the productive sector as a whole.

So, one cannot come to any conclusion other than that the Budget is a disaster and the one consistent element is that the Government that promotes it is also a disaster, and the sooner we get rid of that Government, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1986-87 Budget has been lauded and welcomed by the vast majority of Australians. It has been criticised and condemned by a minority-a minority in most cases with a direct political alliance with the Opposition and certainly by the Opposition itself. An even smaller group, made up of those on the extreme right, acting in chorus with some on the extreme left, have sought to add their voice in the negative to the Budget debate. The Budget is an integral part of the Government's strategy to lift Australia into the real world of international competition. For too long Australians have been denied the opportunity to develop industries which would and could support our primary industries and a diminished manufacturing sector in earning export income.

SPEECH.PARA: Conservative governments-in particular in past years-have failed to realise that those working in farming and mining, whether with their capital or with their trade skills, could not sustain our growing appetite for a higher standard of living and a massive amount of imports. In fact, for seven disastrous years the Fraser Government encouraged cheap imports with an overvalued dollar as a policy weapon allegedly put into place to contain inflationary pressures-inflationary pressures which we were told would come from the famed resources boom, the boom we heard so much about in 1979 and 1980. Where did that resources boom disappear to? What were we left with? We were left with a legacy of massive imports and a manufacturing industry torn apart and a country now trying to redevelop its position to earn the necessary money to sustain our standard of living.

To illustrate this point I remember, back in the early 1980s, in my electorate the State Electricity Commission of Victoria was talking about a plan to establish numerous new power stations in the Latrobe Valley. Thousands of hours of valuable time were wasted on policies of the conservative governments. This was symptomatic of the total lack of credibility in Liberal and National Party policy positions.

Let me turn to this Government's approach. Let us look at the Government's strategy. On 29 May 1983 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the Government had decided to commission a report on the Australian financial system which would have regard to the recommendations of the committees of inquiry into the Australian financial system, the Government's economic and social objectives and the need to improve the efficiency of the financial system. The Government's fundamental objective at that time was interpreted by the group that was established as the implementation of economic policies, including monetary policy, that were directed at combating inflation and reducing unemployment simultaneously. The Government has been successful on both counts. It was further interpreted as being the implementation of policies aimed at ensuring that the benefits of economic growth are equitably distributed and that the pursuit of broad economic objectives proceeds consonantly with the enhancement of opportunities for economically and socially disadvantaged groups in the community. We have certainly succeeded in both those areas. It was interpreted as being the provision of opportunities for Australians to participate in the development of the nation's resources. We are certainly working towards that objective. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his John Curtin Memorial Lecture of September 1983, observed:

Social democrats have no reason to deny the capacity of markets to allocate resources efficiently, or the great productive power that is associated with this capacity. I see no virtue in regulation of economic activity for its own sake, and believe that where markets are working efficiently they should be left to do their job unless there are clear reasons in equity for government intervention.

We are conscious of the various reasons why the workings of a market-oriented system might not always be consistent with the Government's economic and social objectives and the community's overall interests. In such circumstances there will always be occasions for government intervention directed at achieving particular objectives such as economic and institutional stability, more competition, greater equality of opportunity for all Australians and a more equitable distribution of income. The Government does not ignore its responsibilities in these areas. In conjunction with business and the trade union movement-the trade union movement particularly through the prices and incomes accord-the Government has certainly, over the last three years, worked to that particular strategy.

Let me now turn to the outcome of three years of these strategies, bearing in mind the extra liability of a savage decline in commodity prices which developed in the economy 12 months ago. I turn to the recently published 23 September edition of the Bulletin. The article I refer to puts the lie to comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), who spoke before me in the debate. He was indulging in his usual practice of prophesying doom and gloom and attacking wages and the work force. The heading of the article reads `Corporate chiefs scotch talk of recession'. I do not know whom the Deputy Leader of the Opposition claims he represents but certainly, from looking at this article, it is not the business people of Australia. The preface to the article states: `Leaders of Australian business are optimistic about the future. David Haselhurst tells how, to a man, they discount the gloomsayers' talk of an imminent recession'. The article states:

Sir Peter Abeles-managing director of TNT Ltd-was due this week to announce a record net profit for 1985-86 of more than $100m, up from $72.5m previously. Abeles said: `I do not agree a recession is necessarily there. It will depend, of course, half on our own actions and half on the rest of the world's economy. If they (the forecasters) say business will be subdued I would agree with that-but do not forget we have had some very big years.
In saying that he was talking about the last three years. The article continues:

John Saunders, joint managing director of Westfield Holdings Ltd and the manager of Australia's biggest shopping centre trust, said he definitely didn't agree a recession was imminent. He said: `I'm prepared to bet my bottom dollar that if interest rates come down 2 per cent a month before Christmas we'll see a Christmas trading boom. Everybody is trying to paint a picture of gloom which has made people and particularly consumers nervous. I'm not a banker, but I cannot believe interest rates can stay high for more than another three or four months . . .
Brian Quinn-managing director of Coles Myer Ltd-said that while the economy was `recessed' at the moment he questioned the idea that it would worsen.
I do not understand where the honourable member for Menzies gets his advice from when these views come from Australia's business people. Brian Quinn continues:

My own view is that it will not. Things are not as bad domestically as they are being painted. While retail sales are not buoyant they are by no means poor. We're feeling reasonably comfortable about sales leading up to Christmas and about Christmas itself. . . .

On another hopeful note, Quinn said Coles-Myer had significantly lifted its purchases of Australian-made stock as a result of the devalued Australian dollar, particularly in textiles and hard goods such as stationary, crockery and fancy wares. This suggests that the government's budget strategy is working to the extent that it is aimed at holding in domestic demand while at the same time stimulating import replacement and improved exports.
This is a clear indication that the strategy of the last three years, of which this Budget is an integral part, is certainly working. Let us move on:

Treasurer Paul Keating would perhaps get some comfort from the strategies under way at Amcor Ltd-the major packaging, paper, building products and transport group (through its half share in Mayne Nickless Ltd). Amcor managing director Stan Wallis conceded that technically Australia may already be in a recession with little prospect of overall improvement in the short term. But, he said, some segments of industry were now more competitive than ever. `The processing critical issue is-can we capitalise on the opportunity this presents?'

We certainly can capitalise on it, and many people in Australia are capitalising on it. However, it appears that Opposition members, and particularly the honourable member for Menzies, have not been talking to the right people. The article goes on:

Amcor believes that it can. At the end of last month, the company announced it would build a $70m wood processing plant in the Bathurst-Oberon region of New South Wales in joint venture with New Zealand Forest Products Ltd.
The processing plant would produce medium-density fibreboard with an output largely capable of both replacing imports and opening up export opportunities.
Amcor is also spending $60 million on rebuilding its Maryvale plant to expand capacity for making high-quality ``white'' paper and other quality paper now supplied by imports.

Wallis said the company was confident of maintaining steady progress in 1986-87 and `will help to ensure the J curve will be a reality'. To make sure there is no real recession, he said two key objectives must be to ensure minimal wage escalation in the next 18 months and a reduction in interest rates. He also called for more incentives to invest and expand.

From these comments by some of Australia's business people, as reported in the Bulletin, there is every indication that the Government's three-year strategy, of which the Budget is a only an integral part, is working. To come into this House, as the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Menzies, has just done and talk in the mode that he did of doom and gloom, and of the fact that it is all to do with wages, is to forget that a strategy is in place. He seems to ignore the fact that everyone in Australia is aware that we have had an enormous downturn in our commodity prices which has affected our economy drastically. We have had our ability to earn money overseas cut by in excess of 6 per cent. That has fed its way through the economy and has had an impact on the confidence of the nation. However, the strategy that the Government put in place from 1983 on has been not only the correct strategy to put Australia back on the map but also a strategy capable of handling the massive downturn in commodity prices. On top of the normal approach that would have been taken, we have had to deal with the savage blow dealt to us by the overseas situation. The strategy is certainly bearing up.

Every indication, as I have just quoted from the Bulletin, is that there are many opportunities Australian-wide for business to grow and develop. The floating of the dollar, the accord and everything that is in place now is working for the benefit of Australia and Australians. To unnecessarily move in the directions espoused by some of the extreme Right in the country, especially those supported by the honourable member for Menzies, who attacks work practices in a way that seeks confrontation, can only set back that strategy. Anybody who knows anything about industrial relations-I have taken note of the position in my electorate of McMillan and there has not been a serious industrial dispute in the State Electricity Commission of Victoria since 1977-is aware that there has been an ongoing position, especially since the accord was established, to sit down with management and negotiate on work practices. That is happening. It is not something new that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and the Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Howard), have suddenly cottoned on to. It is part of the strategy to which the Government has been working.

The Prime Minister in calling a special meeting in Melbourne next week, has accentuated the fact that it is happening, that there are reasons why the Australian community needs to be aware that it is going on, and that business people in the community should not be duped by the approach taken by the Opposition and some people on the Right in Australia who understand that because of the strategy that has been in place for the past three years, there is a golden opportunity in the next 18 months for the Government that is elected in early 1988 to be the Government that will stay in power in this country for a long time. With the strategy that has been put in place, the opportunities for Australians have never been better since the late 1950s and early 1960s. I strongly support the Budget strategy. I strongly support what the Government is doing. I am sure that by the time the next election comes around the great majority of Australians will concede that and will return the Hawke Government to office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 August this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made the remarkable statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The party is over-finito-and Australians have to understand that it's finito. We are now in a crisis which is as great as the crisis of war.

Two days later, the Dads' Army elected to fight that war brought down the battle plan for the coming year-the Budget. What a disappointment that turned out to be. In our position of crisis, we needed a restoration of incentive, a lifting of government burdens and an encouragement of investment. Instead, we got the old-fashioned, out dated, dog's breakfast of increased taxes and charges-$1,500m worth of them.

In this war situation, as the Prime Minister describes it, the public were crying out for cuts in government expenditure, for the hard decisions to be taken. However, the Government could only muster the courage to run up the pole a flag fashioned out of white feathers. The war cabinet generals who occupy our Government's front bench had decided to lead from behind. The problem areas in our society are the same or worse today as they were the day before the Budget. That is the crux of the failure of the Budget. I refer to indicators such as inflation, interest rates, unemployment, stifling taxes, and our overseas debt. Nothing in that area will change for the better.

I shall deal briefly with each one in turn. Since this Government came to power, the gap between our inflation rate and that of our trading partners has widened. Our rate is running at between 8 and 9 per cent while that of our trading partners is between 0 and 2 per cent. That alone puts enormous downward pressure on our dollar. The Budget has done nothing to improve that. Interest rates, running at near-record levels of nearly 20 per cent, do more than anything to kill off business in this country. They have risen since the Budget due to the direction of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the Reserve Bank of Australia to prop up the dollar, and they will continue to remain high in the foreseeable future.

Unemployment, at 8.3 per cent, is rising and threatens to soar. The Budget prediction is for only a modest increase. Unfortunately, many commentators estimate that levels will reach 10 per cent next year which, in extra dole payments alone, would blow out the Budget by a further $500m. We should not forget that the predicted Budget deficit ran over by $826m last year. The Budget deficit figure of $3.5 billion was in itself a welcome figure-until one realised that it had been arrived at not through cuts in government spending but in increasing taxes. An amount of $1,500m of extra tax has been plucked out of the economy at a time when business is desperately short of investment capital. What an absurdity. The Budget has done almost exactly the opposite of what was needed.

Before considering those taxes, let us look at our overseas debt, which highlights more than any other figure, I believe, the serious financial position Australia is in today. When this Government came to power, our external debt was not much above $25 billion. That was a high enough figure. It had taken 83 years to reach that figure, including the mad spending Whitlam years. What is that debt today? It is something over $86 billion. Next year it will go over $100 billion. This Government has taken three years to triple what it took 83 years to achieve. However, those figures do not tell the full horrific story. The public sector component of that debt is increasing at a rate double that of the private sector component. The terms of the loans that are taken out to cover the debt, which once were measured in years, are now measured in months. An even worse position emerges when we consider what the debt is spent on. In the past, overseas funds were raised to finance investment spending; that is, they were used for investment ventures that would create wealth which would increase the standard of living of us all--

TALK.START.PARA: —The coal mines of the Bowen Basin.

—That is a typical example-and at the same time, service and repay the debt itself. However, today a gigantic and increasing part of the borrowing is used simply to bankroll government consumption spending-in other words, to create little or nothing, and return little or nothing-in non-productive areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Once this sort of pattern emerges, as it has, it has the look of irresponsibility written all over it. It creates uncertainty. It is worthwhile remembering that the debt in this country per head of population is of the order of the debt in Mexico, Argentina and Brazil, and it is only our ability to service that debt which still has us on our present credit rating. But this debt must lead eventually to a downgrading of our credit rating, as is already happening. Our once AAA credit rating has already slipped one notch; I guess that when it finally gets down to a B rating, the B will stand for banana. We are fast becoming the only Third World country in which you can still drink the water.

The state of the economy, as reflected in the falling value of the dollar, is best summed up when we hear that the name of one of the candidates on the Victorian Australian Labor Party Senate ticket for the next election is Halfpenny.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a com, isn't he?
—He used to be. However, if the world's greatest antique collector is not soon relieved of office, perhaps the Victorian Senate candidate should change his name by deed poll to Farthing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now look briefly at some of the Budget taxes and changes. Some time ago the Prime Minister promised that he would cut the fuel price by 3c a litre. What has happened? Federal excise has quadrupled from 6c a litre to 24c a litre in the term of this Government and, in the Budget alone, another $700m is to be extracted out of the Australian economy as a result of a 3c rise. No sooner was the Budget brought down than, eight days later, we had another rise of 2c a litre, which takes another $500m out of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame. Disgraceful.
—It is disgraceful. Only tonight I heard on the news that petrol is to go up again-this is the third rise-in the middle of next month. It is almost beyond belief.

SPEECH.PARA: We all remember the Prime Minister's promise that there would be no sales tax on wine. In the last Budget a sales tax was introduced, and this time it is to be doubled. What about the tax on children? The 10 per cent sales tax on fruit juices, introduced for the first time in this country, will be particularly damaging to the citrus industry, and a 10 per cent sales tax on flavoured milk will do the dairy industry, which is already in desperate straits, no good at all. The Federal bank accounts debits tax will go up by 50 per cent and take another $90m out of the economy. One of the most horrific areas is health. The Medicare levy will go up by 25 per cent to 1.25 per cent of income. There we have another broken promise. Prescription charges will rise by 100 per cent, from $5 to $10. A rise of that proportion is almost beyond belief.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't trust those Labor guys.

—That is quite true. Road funding alone will drop by 8 per cent in real terms in the coming year. Perhaps that was one area where we could have seen an increase in spending. Aboriginal funding is to rise in real terms and will peak at $570m this year. SPEECH.PARA: Funding for Priority One has been increased $67m in a desperate attempt to fulfil the already broken promise that 10,000 jobs would be provided by June this year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first issue that needs to be clarified in the Budget debate is the Government's overall strategy. This Government is set to put in place a comprehensive strategy for the management of the economy. If we reflect on the remarks made by some honourable members opposite, it is evident that they do not have a comprehensive strategy. I find it interesting that they talk about the difficulties that we face on the external account and juxtapose that issue wages, with wages saying that it is a wage-related matter. Their problem in arguing that is that the big loss areas on the external account have been our major commodities. In a general sense, many of those major commodities do not come from labour-intensive industries; they come from capital-intensive industries. So it is very hard to argue, for example, in regard to the drop in the market for iron ore-between 1982 and 1986 iron ore prices have fallen from $US21.90 a tonne to $US16.10 a tonne, which is a reduction of 26 per cent-that the labour component is very significant. It is not. What is significant with respect to that industry is the declining market for iron ore. We are all aware of the impact on demand for iron ore and coal of the decline in the world steel industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give another example in amplification of the argument that I am putting before the House. To take the beef industry, between 1980-81 and 1985-86 the price for Australian boneless frozen beef in the US market fell from an average of $US2.55 a kilo to $US1.95 a kilo-down 24 per cent. The most recent price was $US1.84 a kilo. Again we are not talking about an industry which is labour-intensive. In terms of the total output of that industry, labour tends to be a relatively small component, so it is very difficult to sustain an argument that focuses upon wages policy and says that the impact of the wages policy has caused a decline in those markets. It does not hold.

I shall return later in the debate to say that we need a comprehensive central wage-fixing policy, which is what we have, to address the whole question of wages. It is something which Opposition members have chosen to shy away from, and it does them no credit. It will do them no credit out there in the electorate until they have addressed the major issue of wages policy.

Let me also turn in this analysis to coal. Between 1982-83 and 1985-86 average coal export prices have fallen from $US54.85 a tonne to $US39.41 a tonne-down 28 per cent. The most recent prices are about $US31.72 a tonne. Again we are not talking about an industry which, in terms of volume, is impacted upon very much by wages. Indeed, with the large open cut mines the wage component in the coal industry is quite small. The argument being advanced by honourable members opposite-the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) is one of those-that somehow our wages policy is central to the decline in those export industries just does not hold up. We are talking about industries which have declined due to other factors, and they are not wage factors. They are declining due to economic conditions-that is, the demand for those industries into which those commodities go and, beyond that, the health of the economies which use those finished products for which those commodities constitute a basic resource.

I turn to another example. Let us look at silver. Between February 1983 and August 1986 the London Metal Exchange-LME-silver price fell from $US13.97 an ounce to $US5.31 an ounce-down 62 per cent. Again, the wage component in that is very small. What we are talking about is a market-related factor. The market-related factor is that there has been a decline in those particular commodities and those markets. I find it interesting to have to make these remarks, given the fact that the Opposition is presenting itself as a market-oriented party. I find that difficult to sustain; nevertheless, it tries to argue that. What we are talking about is market factors and market forces at work in relation to commodity prices.

What we are saying in this place is that if one wants to go down the path that the Opposition wants to go down-that is, of a deregulated wage system-one will see market forces at work and the kind of wage conditions that characterised the market-place in 1981-82, in what one might call the staggering final years of the Fraser Government. The Australian community has not forgotten that; nor have we on our side, because we recognise the deficiencies of that approach to policy making. We will not risk that again, because clearly the Opposition is not capable of putting together a series of comprehensive wages or other policies.

I will round off this segment of the argument by talking about some other commodity movements. I refer to wheat which, again, is not a labour-intensive industry. However, between 1980-81 and 1985-86, wheat prices fell from $US181.90 a tonne to $US133 a tonne-down 27 per cent. The most recent price is about $US103 a tonne. We are all aware of the impact that subsidised United States wheat sales are having on our potential to sell wheat to markets. We must focus on the external conditions that shape the market for our commodities. For the Opposition to argue that the central focus of the economic debate is applied by wages policy is to miss the substance of the economic forces at work.

I would like to develop the argument further. Obviously, time will prevent me from completing my arguments this evening. But what we on this side have is a series of policies which fit together. We have fiscal policy which, fundamentally, the Budget incorporates. We have monetary policy which has been a central element in our policy making this year. We have a trade policy. We also have a wages policy. We have a foreign credit policy-and external policy. All of those aspects fit together. What we are waiting on, in terms of the Australian debate, is to find out the Opposition's policies. It has an industrial relations policy, but it has not carried very much weight with the audience to which it has been addressed. In fact, that audience has been very unreceptive of its industrial relations policy. If we look at the way in which the policy is being developed, we see that it is really one which tends to try to borrow some of the more extreme elements of the Australian political scene. What we on this side of the House are concerned about is to put together a comprehensive policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ratbag element.

—As my friend the honourable member for Melbourne says, it is the ratbag element. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) need not turn to acknowledge those comments. We well know that there are some substantial problems with respect to the Opposition's wages policy. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk tonight about a matter of double standards. I want to talk about someone who should be purer than Caesar's wife. SPEECH.PARA: Recently I was in Karratha-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members on both sides of the House are concerned about the `black' economy. Literally billions of dollars escape the tax net annually, thereby depriving the Commonwealth of vital revenue and shortchanging the innocent taxpayers of Australia-and, I might add, shortchanging the homeless as a result of the increases to which attention was drawn by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand).

SPEECH.PARA: The recent debate on the fringe benefits tax has raised some interesting questions about which I earnestly seek information in the form of specific answers so that I might properly advise my constituents as to their rights, duties and obligations. I am aware, for example, of the confusion relating to travel-travel not just on the ground but in the air. I would like to know, for example, whether the fringe benefits tax is payable on free helicopter travel provided by a company both for its own benefit and for the benefit of the persons enjoying the free helicopter ride.

I would like to know also what is the position with respect to loans at very concessional interest rates made, for example, by statutory authorities in New South Wales to officers or employees of the Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union. If the loan is advanced to procure industrial peace and if the interest rate is unbelievably low, is a fringe benefits tax payable by the lender, or is additional tax payable by the borrower on the basis of the financial advantages accrued by the very favourable terms, including interest rates?

Specifically, I also seek information as to the basis upon which property transactions are now to be taxed, having regard particularly to the capital gains tax and the person engaged in property and chattel transactions who does not declare himself to be an investor and relies on some other form of remuneration, purportedly involving full time employment, for example as a member of this Parliament. Are these property transactions declarable in the register of members' interests? At what rate of tax are the said transactions assessed by the Australian Taxation Office? Do the same rules apply to valuable assets other than real estate and including antiques, clocks and objects d'art?

What principles apply in relation to the taxation rate on joint venture business operations and the profits arising therefrom when the parties concerned are from both the public sector and the private sector? What is the position if one of the parties is, for example, a member of parliament and the other is engaged solely in private enterprise? Is the position aggravated if the private enterprise person is engaged in bottom of the harbour activities and has therefore deliberately evaded paying tax which was lawfully due? What is the position if the private enterprise person has filed an incorrect return as to the amount of profit made by his companies. Finally, I seek clarification of a position where a person in public office provides, for valuable consideration, letters of introduction and references to a person in private enterprise for the expressed purpose of assisting that person to obtain preferential financial commitment. Is the financial benefit thereupon conferred subject to tax and, if so, at what rate? I raise these matters in the public interest because in each instance prima facie evidence is raised against the Treasurer (Mr Keating). These things have been done by the honourable member for Blaxland, the Treasurer of Australia.
